DIV1.P: The Witch of Edmonton: A known true STORY.
Composed into A TRAGI-COMEDY By divers well-esteemed Poets; William Rowley, Thomas Dekker, Iohn Ford, &c.
Acted by the Princes Servants, often at the Cock-Pit in Drury-Lane, once at Court, with singular Applause.
London, Printed by J. Cottrel, for Edward Blackmore, at the Angel in Pul's Church-yard. 1658.

DIV1.HEAD: The whole Argument is this Dystich.
DIV1.L: FOrc'd Marriage, Murder; Murder, Blood requires:
Reproach, Revenge; Revenge, Hells help desires.

LG.L: THe Town of Edmonton hath lent the Stage
A Devil and a Witch, both in an age.
To make comparisons it were uncivil,
Between so even a pair, a Witch and Devil.
But as the year doth with his plenty bring
As well a latter as a former Spring;
So has this Witch enioy'd the first, and reason
Presumes she may partake the other season:
In Acts deserving name, the Proverb says,
Once good, and ever; Why not so in Plays?
Why not in this? since (Gentlemen) we flatter
No Expectation: here is Mirth and Matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: COme, Wench; why here's a business soon dispatch'd.
Thy heart I know is now at ease: thou needst not
Fear what the tattling Gossips in their cups
Can speak against thy fame: thy childe shall know
Who to call Dad now.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: You have discharg'd the true part of an honest man;
I cannot request a fuller satisfaction
Then you have freely granted: yet methinks
'Tis an hard case, being lawful man and wife,
We should not live together.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Had I fail'd
In promise of my truth to thee, we must
Have then been ever sundred; now the longest
Of our forbearing eithers company,
Is onely but to gain a little time
For our continuing thrift, that so hereafter
The Heir that shall be born may not have cause
To curse his hour of birth, which made him feel
The misery of beggery and want;
Two Devils that are occasions to enforce
A shameful end. My plots aim but to keep
My father's love.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: And that will be as difficult
To be preserv'd, when he shall understand
How you are married, as it will be now,
Should you confess it to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Fathers are
Wonne by degrees, not bluntly as our masters,
Or wronged friends are: and besides, I'll use
Such dutiful and ready means, that ere
He can have notice of what's past, th' inheritance
To which I am born Heir, shall be assur'd:
That done, why let him know it; if he like it not,
Yet he shall have no power in him left
To cross the thriving of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: You who had
The conquest of my Maiden-love, may easily
Conquer the fears of my distrust. And whither
Must I be hurried?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Prithee do not use
A word so much unsuitable to the constant
Affections of thy Husband: thou shalt live
Neer Waltham Abbey, with thy Unkle Slman:
I have acquainted him with all at large:
He'll use thee kindly: thou shalt want no pleasures,
Nor any other fit supplies whatever
Thou canst in heart desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: All these are nothing
Without your company.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Which thou shalt have
Once every month at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Once every month!
Is this to have an Husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Perhaps oftner:
That's as occasion serves.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: I, I, in case
No other Beauty tempt your eye, whom you
Like better, I may chance to be remembred,
And see you now and then. Faith, I did hope
You'ld not have us'd me so: 'tis but my fortune.
And yet, if not for my sake, have some pity
Upon the childe I go with, that's your own.
And, less you'll be a cruel hearted Father,
You cannot but remember that.
Heaven knows how.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: To quit which fear at once,
As by the ceremony late perform'd,
I plighted thee a faith, as free from challenge,
As any double thought; Once more in hearing
Of Heaven and thee, I vow, that never henceforth
Disgrace, reproof, lawless affections, threats,
Or what can be suggested gainst our Marriage,
Shall cause me falsifie that Bridal-Oath
That bindes me thine. And, Winnifride, when ever
The wanton heat of youth by subtle baits
Of beauty, or what womans Art can practice,
Draw me from onely loving thee; let Heaven
Inflict upon my life some fearful ruine.
I hope thou dost believe me.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Swear no more;
I am confirm'd, and will resolve to do
What you think most behoofeful for us.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Thus then; make thy self ready: at the furthest house
Upon the Green, without the Town, your Unckle
Expects you. For a little time farewel.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Sweet,
We shall meet again as soon as thou canst possibly?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: We shall. One kiss. Away.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Frank Thorney.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Here Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.P: Alone? then must I tell thee in plain terms, thou hast wrong'd thy Master's house basely and lewdly.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Your house, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Yes, Sir, if the nimble devil
That wanton'd in your blood, rebell'd against
All rules of honest duty. You might, Sir,
Have found out some more fitting place then here,
To have built a Stewes in. All the Country whispers
How shamefully thou hast undone a Maid,
Approv'd for modest life, for civil carriage,
Till thy prevailing perjuries entic'd her
To forfeit shame. Will you be honest yet?
Make her amends and marry her?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: So, Sir,
I might bring both my self and her to beggery;
And that would be a shame worse then the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: You should have thought on this before, and then
Your reason would have oversway'd the passion
Of your unruly lust. But that you may
Be left without excuse, to salve the infamy
Of my disgraced house, and 'cause you are
A Gentleman, and both of you my servants,
I'll make the Maid a portion.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: So you promis'd me
Before, in case I married her. I know
Sir Arthur Clarington deserves the credit
Report hath lent him; and presume you are
A Debtor to your promise: but upon
What certainty shall I resolve? Excuse me
For being somewhat rude.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: 'Tis but reason.
Well Frank, what thinkst thou of 200 l.
And a continual friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.L: Though my poor fortunes
Might happily prefer me to a choice
Of a far greater portion; yet to right
A wronged Maid, and to preserve your favour,
I am content to accept your proffer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Art thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Sir, we shall every day have need to employ
The use of what you please to give.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Thou shalt have't.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Then I claim your promise.
We are man and wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Already?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: And more then so, I have promis'd her
Free entertainment in her Unkle's house,
Neer Waltham Abbey, where she may securely
So journe, till time and my endeavours work
My fathers love and liking.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Honest Frank.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I hope, Sir, you will think I cannot keep her
Without a daily charge.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: As for the money,
'Tis all thine own; and though I cannot make thee
A present payment, yet thou shalt be sure
I will not fail thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: But our occasions.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.P: Nay, nay, talk not of your occasions, trust my boun∣ty: it shall not sleep. Hast married her, yfaith Frank?
SP.L: 'Tis well, 'tis passing well: then Winnifride,
Once more thou art an honest woman. Frank,
Thou hast a Jewel. Love her; she'll deserve it.
And when to Waltham?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: She is making ready.
Her Unkle stays for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Most provident speed.
Frank, I will be friend, and such a friend.
Thou'lt bring her thither?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Sir, I cannot: newly
My father sent me word I should come to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Marry, and do: I know thou hast a wit
To handle him.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I have a suit t'ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: What is't?
Any thing, Frank, command it.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: That you'll please,
By Letters to assure my Father, that
I am not married.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Some one or other
Hath certainly inform'd him that I purpos'd
To marry Winnifride; on which he threatned
To dis-inherit me, to prevent it,
Lowly I crave your Letters, which he seeing
Will credit; and I hope ere I return,
On such conditions as I'll frame, his Lands
Shall be assur'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: But what is that to quit
My knowledge of the marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Why you were not
A witness to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: I conceive: and then,
His Land confirmed, thou wilt acquaint him throughly
With all that's past.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I mean no less.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Provided,
I never was made privy to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Alas, Sir,
Am I a talker?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Draw thy self the Letter,
I'll put my hand to it. I commend thy policy
Th'art witty, witty Frank; nay, nay, 'tis fit,
Dispatch it.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I shall write effectually.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Go thy way Cuckow; have I caught the young man?
One trouble then is freed. He that will feast
At others cost, must be a bold fac'd guest.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: I have heard the news, all now is safe.
The worst is past.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Thy lip, wench: I must bid
Farewel, for fashions sake; but I will visit thee
Suddenly, Girl. This was cleanly carried:
Ha! was't not Win?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Then were my happiness,
That I in heart repent I did not bring him
The Dower of a Virginity. Sir, forgive me;
I have been much to blame. Had not my Laundress
Given way to your immoderate waste of Vertue,
You had not with such eagerness pursu'd
The error of your goodness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Dear, dear Win.
I hug this Art of thine, it snews how cleanly
Thou canst beguile in case occasion serve,
To practice. It becomes thee, now we share
Free scope enough, without controle or fear,
To interchange our pleasures; we will surfeit
In our embraces, Wench. Come, tell me, when
Wilt thou appoint a meeting?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: What to do?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Good, good, to con the lesson of our loves,
Our secret game.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: O blush to speak it further!
As y' are a noble Gentleman, forget
A sin so monstrous: 'tis not gently done,
To open a cur'd wound. I know you speak
For trial; troth you need not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: I for trial?
Not I, by this good Sun-shine.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Can you name
That syllable of good, and yet not tremble,
To think to what a foul and black intent,
You use it for an Oath? Let me resolve you,
If you appear in any Visitation
That brings not with it pity for the wrongs
Done to abused Thorney, my kinde husband;
If you infect mine ear with any breath
That is not throughly perfum'd with sighs
For former deeds of lust: May I be curs'd
Even in my prayers, when I vouchsafe
To see or hear you. I will change my life,
From a loose whore, to a repentant wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Wilt thou turn monster now? art not asham'd
After so many months to be honest at last?
Away, away, fie on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: My resolution
Is built upon a Rock. This very day
Young Thorney vow'd with Oaths not to be doubted,
That never any change of love should cancel
The bonds in which we are to either bound,
Of lasting truth. And shall I then for my part
Unfile the sacred Oath set on Record
In Heaven's Book? Sir Arthur, do not study
To add to your lascivious lust, the sin
Of Sacriledge: for if you but endeavour
By any unchaste word to tempt my constancy,
You strive as much as in you lies to ruine
A Temple hallowed to the purity
Of holy Marriage. I have said enough:
You may believe me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Get you to your Nunnery,
There freeze in your old Cloyster. This is fine.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Good Angels guide me. Sir, you'l give me leave
To weep and pray for your coersion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Yes, away to Waltham. Pox on your honesty.
Had you no other trick to fool me? Well,
You may want mony yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: None that I'll send for
To you, for hire of a damnation.
When I am gone, think on my just complaint:
I was your Devil, O be you my Saint!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Go, go thy ways, as changeable a baggage
As ever cozen'd Knight. I'm glad I'm rid of her.
Honest? marry hang her. Thorney is my Debtor,
I thought to have paid him too: but fools have fortune.

SP.STAGE: Enter Old Thorney, and Old Carter.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: You offer Mr. Carter, like a Gentleman,
I cannot finde fault with it, 'tis so fair.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Cart.
SP.P: No Gentleman, I, Mr. Thorney; spare the Mastership, call me by my name, John Carter; Master is a title my Father, nor his before him, were acquainted with. Honest Hertforshire Yeo∣men, such an one am I; my word and my deed shall be proved one at all times. I mean to give you no security for the Marriage∣money.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.P: How? no security? although it need not, so long as you live; yet who is he has surety of his life one hour? Men, the Proverb says, are mortal: else, for my part, I distrust you not, were the sum double.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Cart.
SP.P: Double, trebble, more or less; I tell you, Mr. Thor∣ney, I'll give no security. Bonds and Bills are but Tarriers to catch Fools, and keep lazy Knaves busie; my security shall be pre∣sent payment. And we here, about Edmonton, hold present pay∣ment as sure as an Alderman's Bond in London, Mr. Thorney.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: I cry you mercy, Sir, I understood you not.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Cart.
SP.P: I like young Frank well, so does my Susan too. The Girl has a fancy to him, which makes me ready in my Purse. There be other Suitors within, that make much noise to little purpose. If Frank love Sue, Sue shall have none but Frank. 'Tis a man∣nerly Girl, Mr. Thorney, though but an homely man's Daughter. There have worse Faces look'd out of black Bags, Man.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.P: You speak your minde freely and honestly. I mar∣vel my Son comes not: I am sure he will be here sometime to day.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Cart.
SP.P: To day or to morrow, when he comes he shall be wel∣come to Bread, Beer and Beef, Yoeman's fare; we have no Kick∣shaws: full Dishes, whole belly-fulls. Should I diet three days at one of the slender City-Suppers, you might send me to Barber-Sur∣geons Hall the fourth day, to hang up for an Anatomy.—Here come they that—

How now Girls? every day play-day with you? Enter VVarbeck with Susan, Somerton with Katherine. Valentine's day too, all by couples? Thus will young folks do when we are laid in our Graves, Mr. Thorney. Here's all the care they take. And how do you finde the VVenches, Gentlemen? have they any minde to a loose Gown and a strait Shooe? VVin'em, and wear'em. They shall chuse for themselves by my consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.P: You speak like a kinde Father. Sue, thou hearest the liberty that 's granted thee. VVhat sayest thou? wilt thou be mine?

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Your what, Sir? I dare swear, never your wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.P: Canst thou be so unkinde? considering how dearly I af∣fect thee; nay, dote on thy perfections.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: You are studied too Scholar-like in words: I understand not. I am too course for such a Gallants love as you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: By the honour of Gentility.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Good Sir, no swearing: yea and nay with us
Prevails above all oathes you can invent.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: By this white hand of thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: Take a false oath? Fie, fie, flatter the wise: fools not regard it; and one of these am I.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: Dost thou despise me?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Cart.
SP.P: Let 'em talk on, Mr. Thorney. I know Sue's minde. The Flye may buz about the Candle, he shall but singe his VVings when all 's done. Frank, Frank is he has her heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: But shall I live in hope, Kate?

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: Better so, then be a desperate man.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: Perhaps thou thinkst it is thy Portion
I level at: wert thou as poor in Fortunes,
As thou art rich in Goodness; I would rather
Be Suitor for the Dower of thy Vertues,
Then twice thy Father 's whole Estate; and prithee
Be thou resolved so.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: Mr. Somerton, it is an easie labour to deceive
A Maid that will believe Mens subtil promises:
Yet I conceive of you as worthily
As I presume you do deserve.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: Which is
As worthily in loving thee sincerely,
As thou art worthy to be so belov'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: I shall finde time to try you.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: Do, Kate, do:
And when I fail, may all my joys forsake me.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Cart.
SP.P: Warbeck and Sue are at it still. I laugh to my self, Mr. Thorney, to see how earnestly he beats the Bush, while the Bird is flown into anothers bosom. A very unthrift, Mr. Thorney; one of the Country roaring Lads: we have such as well as the City, and as arrant Rake-hells as they are, though not so nimble at their prizes of wit. Sue knows the Raskal to an hairs breadth, and will fit him accordingly.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: What is the other Gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Cart.
SP.P: One Somerton, the honester man of the two, by 5 l. in every stone-weight. A civil Fellow. He has a fine convenient E∣state of land in West-ham by Essex. M. Ranges that dwells by Enfield, sent him hither. He likes Kate well. I may tell you, I think she likes him as well. If they agree, I'll not hinder the match for my part. But that Warbeck is such another—. I use him kindly for Mr. Somerton's sake: for he came hither first as a Companion of his. Honest men, Mr. Thorney, may fall into Knaves company, now and then.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: Three hundred a yeer Joynture, Sue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Where lies it, by Sea or by Land? I think by Sea.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: Do I look like a Captain?

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Not a whit, Sir.
Should all that use the Seas be reckon'd Captains,
There 's not a Ship should have a Scullion in her
To keep her clean.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: Do you scorn me, Mrs. Susan▪
Am I a subject to be jeer'd at?

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Neither
Am I a property for you to use
As stale to your fond wanton loose discourse.
Pray Sir be civil.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: VVilt be angry, VVasp?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Cart.
SP.P: God-a-mercy, Sue. She'll firk him on my life, if he fumble with her.
SP.L: Mr. Francis Thorney, you are welcome indeed.
SP.P: Your Father expected your coming. How does the right worship∣ful Knight, Sir Arthur Clarington, your Master?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: In health this morning. Sir, my duty.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: Now
You come as I could wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: Frank Thorney, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: You must excuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Vertuous. Mrs Susan.
Kinde Mrs. Katherine. Gentlemen, to both
Good time o'th' day.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: The like to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: 'Tis he.
A word, Friend. On my life, this is the Man
Stands fair in crossing Susan's love to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: I think no less. Be wise, and take no notice on't.
He that can wi her, best deserves her.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: Marry
A Servingman? mew.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: Prethee Friend no more.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Cart.
SP.P: Gentlemen all, there's within a slight Dinner ready, if you please to taste of it: Mr. Thorney, Mr. Francis, Mr. Somer∣ton. VVhy Girls? what, Huswives, will you spend all your fore∣noon in tittle-tattles? away: It's well yfaith. VVill you go in, Gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: VVe'll follow presently: my Son and I
Have a few words of business.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Cart.
SP.L: At your pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: I think you guess the reason, Frank, for which
I sent for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: I need not tell you.
VVith what a labyrinth of dangers dayly
The best part of my whole Estate's encumbred:
Nor have I any Clew to winde it out,
But what occasion proffers me. VVherein
If you should faulter, I shall have the shame,
And you the loss. On these two points relie
Our hapiness or ruine. If you marry
VVith wealthy Carter's Daughter, there's a Portion
VVill free my Land: all which I will instate
Upon the marriage to you. Otherwise.
I must be of necessity enforc'd
To make a present sale of all: and yet,
For ougt I know, live in as poor distress,
Or worse, then now I do. You hear the sum:
I told you thus before. Have you considered on't?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I have, Sir. And however I could wish
To enjoy the benefit of single Freedom,
For that I finde no disposition in me
To undergo the burthen of that care
That Marriage brings with it; Yet to secure
And settle the continuance of your Credit,
I humbly yield to be directed by you
In all commands.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: You have already us'd
Such thriving protestations to the Maid.
That she is wholly yours. And speak the truth,
You love her, do you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: 'Twere pity, Sir,
I should deceive her.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: Better y had been unborn.
But is your love so steady that you mean,
Nay, more, desire to make her your Wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Else, Sir,
It were a wrong not to be righted.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: True,
It were: and you will marry her?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Heaven prosper it:
I do intend it.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: O thou art a Villain!
A Devil like a Man. VVherein have I
Offended all the Powers so much, to be
Father to such a graceless godless Son?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: To me, Sir, this? O my cleft heart!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: To thee,
Son of my curse. Speak truth, and blush, thou monster,
Hast thou not married Winnifride? a Maid
Was fellow-servant with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.L: Some swift spirit
Has blown this news abroad. I must out-face it.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: D'you study for excuse? why all the country
Is full on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Fra.
SP.L: With your license, 'tis not charitable,
I am sure it is not fatherly, so much
To be o'resway'd with credulous conceit
Of meer impossibilities. But Fathers
Are priviledg'd to think and talk at pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: Why canst thou yet deny thou hast no wise?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: What do you take me for? an Atheist?
One that nor hopes the blessedness of life
Hereafter, neither fears the vengeance due
To such as make the Marriage-bed an Inne,
VVhich Travellers day and night,
After a toylsome lodging leave at pleasure?
Am I become so insensible of losing
The glory of Creations work? My soul!
O I have liv'd too long.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: Thou hast, dissembler;
Darest thou persevere yet? and pull down wrath
As hot as flames of hell, to strike thee quick
Into the Grave of horror? I believe thee not.
Get from my sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Sir, though mine innocence
Needs not a stronger witness then the cleerness
Of an unperish'd conscience; yet for that
I was enform'd, how mainly you had been
Possess'd of this untruth, To quit all scruple
Please you peruse this Letter: 'tis to you.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: From whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Sir Arthur Clarington my Master.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: Well, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: On every side I am distracted: Am waded deeper into mischief, then vertue can avoid. But on I must: Fate leads me: I will follow. There you read what may confirm you.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.P: Yes, and wonder at it. Forgive me, Frank. Credulity abus'd me. My tears express my joy: and I am sorry I injur'd in∣nocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Alas! I knew your rage and grief proceeded from your love to me: so I conceiv'd it.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.P: My good Son, I'll bear with many faults in thee here∣after. Bear thou with mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: The peace is soon concluded.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Cart.
SP.P: VVhy Mr. Thorney, d'ye mean to talk out your din∣ner? the Company attends your coming. What must it be, Mr. Frank▪ or Son Frank? I am plain Dunstable.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: Son, Brother, if your Daughter like to have it so.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I dare be confident, she's not alter'd
From what I left her at our parting last:
Are you, fair Maid?

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: You took too sure possession
Of an engaged heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Which now I challenge.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Cart.
SP.P: Marry and much good may it do thee, Son. Take her to thee. Get me a brace of Boys at a burthen, Frank. The nur∣sing shall not stand thee in a pennyworth of Milk. Reach her home and spare not. VVhen's the day?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: To morrow, if you please. To use ceremony
Of charge and custome, were to little purpose:
Their loves are married fast enough already.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Cart.
SP.P: A good motion. VVe'll e'en have an houshold Din∣ner; and let the Fiddlers go scrape. Let the Bride and Bridegroom dance at night together: no matter for the Guests. To morrow, Sue, to morrow. Shall's to Dinner now?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: VVe are on all sides pleas'd, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Pray Heaven I may deserve the blessing sent me.
Now my heart is settled.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: So is mine.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Cart.
SP.L: Your Marriage-money shall be receiv'd before your
VVedding-shooes can be pull'd on. Blessing on you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: No Man can hide his shame from Heaven that views him.
In vain he flees, whose destiny pursues him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: ANd why on me? why should the envious world
Throw all their scandalous malice upon me?
'Cause I am poor, deform'd and ignorant,
And like a Bow buckl'd and bent together,
By some more strong in mischiefs then my self?
Must I for that be made a common sink,
For all the filth and rubbish of Men's tongues
To fall and run into? Some call me VVitch;
And being ignorant of my self, they go
About to teach me how to be one: urging,
That my bad tongue (by their bad usage made so)
Forespeaks their Cattle, doth bewitch their Corn,
Themselves, their Servants, and their Babes at nurse.
This they enforce upon me: and in part
Make me to credit it. And here comes one
Of my chief Adversaries.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.L: Out, out upon thee, VVitch.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Dost call me VVitch?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.P: I do, VVitch, I do: and worse I would, knew I a name more hateful. VVhat makest thou upon my ground?

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Gather a few rotten sticks to warm me.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.L: Down with them when I bid thee, quickly;
I'll make thy bones rattle in thy skin else.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: You-won't, Churl. Cut-throat, Miser: there they be. VVould they stuck cross thy throat, thy bowels, thy maw, thy midriff.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.L: Sayst thou me so? Hag, out of my ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: Dost strike me▪ slave? curmudgeon now thy bones aches, thy joynts cramps, and convulsions stretch and crack thy sinews.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.L: Cursing, thou Hag! take that, and that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Strike, do, and wither'd may that hand and arm
Whose blows have lam'd me, drop from the rotten Trunk.
Abuse me! beat me! call me Hag and Witch!
What is the name? where and by what Art learn'd?
What spells, what charms, or invocations?
May the thing call'd Familiar be purchas'd?
SP.STAGE: Enter Young Banks, and three or four more.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: A new head for the Tabor, and silver tipping for the Pipe. Remember that, and forget not five lesh of new Bells.

SP.L: Double Bells: Crooked Lane ye shall have 'em straight in.
Crooked Lane: double Bells all, if it be possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: Double Bells? double Coxcombs; Trebles: buy me Trebles, all Trebles: for our purpose is to be in the Altitudes.

SP.L: All Trebles? not a Mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: Not one: The Morrice is so cast, we'll have neither Mean nor Base in our company, Fellow Rowland.

SP.L: VVhat? nor a Counter?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: By no means, no hunting Counter; leave that to En∣vile Chase-Men: all Trebles, all in the Altitudes. Now for the disposing of Parts in the Morrice, little or no labour will serve.
If you that be minded to follow your Leader, know me, an ancient Honor belonging to our house, for a Fore-horse, team, and for gallant in a Morrice: my Father's Stable is not unfurnish'd.

SP.L: So much for the Fore-horse: but how for a good Hobby-horse?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: For a Hobby-horse? Let me see an Almanack. Midsummer-Moon, let me see ye. VVhen the Moon's in the full, then's wit in the wane. No more. Use your best skill. Your Mor∣rice will suffer an Eclipse.

SP.L: An Eclipse?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.L: A strange one.
Strange?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: Yes, and most sudden. Remember the For gallant, and forget the Hobby-horse. The whole body of your Morrice will be darkned. There be of us. But 'tis no matter. Forget the Hoby-horse.
Cuddy Banks, have you forgot since he pac'd it from Envile Chase to Edmonton? Cuddy, honest Cuddy, cast thy stuff.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: Suffer may ye all. It shall be known, I can take mine ease as well as another Man. Seek your Hobby-horse where you can get him.

SP.L: Cuddy, honest Cuddy, we confess, and are sorry for our neglect.
The old Horse shall have a new Bridle.
The Caparisons new painted.
The Tail repair'd.
The Snaffle and the Bosses new saffron'd o're.
Kinde:
Honest:
Loving, ingenious:
Affable Cuddy.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: To shew I am not flint; but affable, as you say, very well stuft, a kinde of warm Dowe or Puff-paste, I relent, I connive, most affable Jack: let the Hobby-horse provide a strong back, he shall not want a belly when I am in 'em. But Uds me, Mother Sawyer.

SP.L: The old Witch of Edmonton. If our mirth be not cross'd.

SP.P: Bless us, Cuddy, and let her curse her tother eye out. VVhat dost now?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: Ungirt, unbless'd, says the Proverb. But my Girdle shall serve a riding knit: and a fig for all the VVitches in Chri∣stendom. VVhat wouldst thou?

SP.L: The Divel cannot abide to be cross'd.
And scorns to come at any man's whistle.
Away
VVith the VVitch.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Away with the VVitch of Edmonton.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Still vex'd? still tortur'd? That Curmudgeon Banks
Is ground of all my scandal. I am shunn'd
And hated like a sickness: made a scorn
To all degrees and sexes. I have heard old Beldames
Talk of Familiars in the shape of Mice,
Rats, Ferrets, VVeasels, and I wot not what,
That have appear'd, and suck'd, some say, their blood.
But by what means they came acquainted with them,
I'm now ignorant: would some power good or bad
Instruct me which way I might be reveng'd
Upon this Churl, I'd go out of my self,
And give this Fury leave to dwell within
This ruin'd Cottage, ready to fall with age:
Abjure all goodness: be at hate with prayer;
And study Curses, Imprecations,
Blasphemous speeches, Oaths, detested Oaths,
Or any thing that's ill; so I might work
Revenge upon this Miser, this black Cur,
That barks, and bites, and sucks the very blood
Of me, and of my credit. 'Tis all one,
To be a VVitch, as to be counted one.
Vengeance, shame, ruine, light upon that Canker.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Ho! have I found thee cursing? now thou art mine own.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Thine? what art thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: He thou hast so often importun'd to appear to thee, the Devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Bless me! the Devil?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Come, do not fear, I love thee much too well
To hurt or fright thee. If I seem terrible,
It is to such as hate me. I have found
Thy love unfeign'd; have seen and pitied
Thy open wrongs, and come out of my love
To give thee just revenge against thy foes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: May I believe thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: To confirm't, command me
Do any mischief unto Man or Beast,
And I'll effect it, on condition,
That uncompell'd thou make a deed of Gift
Of Soul and Body to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Out, alas!
My Soul and Body?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: And that instantly,
And seal it with thy blood: if thou deniest,
I'll tear thy body in a thousand pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: I know not where to seek relief: But shall I
After such Covenants seal'd, see full revenge
On all that wrong me?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Ha, ha, silly woman!
The Devil is no lyer to such as he loves.
Didst ever know or hear the Devil a lyer
To such as he affects?

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: VVhen I am thine, at least so much of me,
As I can call mine own.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Equivocations?
Art mine or no? speak, or I'll tear.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: All thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Seal't with thy blood.
See, now I dare call thee mine;
For proof, command me, instantly I'll run,
To any mischief, goodness can I none.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: And I desire as little. There's an old Churl, one Banks—

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: That wrong'd thee: he lam'd thee, call'd thee VVitch.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: The same: first upon him I'ld be reveng'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Thou shalt: Do but name how.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Go, touch his life.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: I cannot.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Hast thou not vow'd? Go, kill the slave.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: I wonnot.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: I'll cancel then my gift.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Dost laugh?
VVhy wilt not kill him?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Fool, because I cannot.
Though we have power, know, it is circumscrib'd,
And ti'd in limits: though he be curs'd to thee,
Yet of himself he is loving to the world,
And charitable to the poor. Now Men
That, as he, love goodness, though in smallest measure,
Live without compass of our reach. His Cattle
And Corn, I'll kill and mildew: but his life
(Until I take him, as I late found thee,
Cursing and swearing) I have no power to touch.

SP.SPEAKER: Saw.
SP.L: Work on his corn and cattle then.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: I shall.
The VVitch of Edmonton shall see his fall.
If she at least put credit in my power,
And in mine onely; make Orisons to me,
And none but me.

SP.SPEAKER: Saw.
SP.L: Say how, and in what manner?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: I'll tell thee, when thou wishest ill;
Corn, Man or Beast, would spoyl or kill,
Turn thy back against the Sun,
And mumble this short Orison:

L.HI: If thou to death or shame pursue 'em,
If thou to death or shame pursue 'em,

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Perfect. Farewel. Our first-made promises
We'll put in execution against Banks.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Contaminetur nomen tuum. I'm an expert Scholar;
Speak Latine, or I know not well what Language,
As well as the best of 'em. But who comes hee?
The Son of my worst Foe. To death pursue 'em,

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.L: What 's that she mumbles? the Devils Pater noster?
Would it were else. Mother Sawyer, Good morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: Ill morrow to thee, and all the world, that flout a poor old woman. To death pursue 'em, and sanctabacetur nomen tuum.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.L: Nay, good Gammer Sawyer, what e're it pleases my
Father to call you, I know you are

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: A Witch.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.L: A Witch? would you were else yfaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Your Father knows I am by this.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.L: I would he did.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: And so in time may you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: I would I might else. But Witch or no Witch, you are a motherly woman: and though my Father be a kinde of God bless us, as they say, I have an earnest suit to you; and if you'll be so kinde to ka me one good turn, I'll be so courteous as to kob you another.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: VVhat's that? to spurn, beat me, and call me VVitch, as your kinde Father doth?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: My Father? I am asham'd to own him. If he has hurt the head of thy credit, there's money to buy thee a Playster: and a small courtesie I would require at thy hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: You seem a good young Man, and I must dissemble, the better to accomplish my revenge. But for this silver, what wouldst have me do? bewitch thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P:
No, by no means; I am bewitch'd already. I would
have thee so good as to unwitch me, or witch another with me for company.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: I understand thee not. Be plain, my Son.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.L: As a Pike-staff, Mother: you know Kate Carter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: The wealthy Yeomans Daughter. What of her?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.L: That same Party has bewitch'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Bewitch'd thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: Bewitch'd me, Hisce auribus. I saw a little Devil flie out of her eye like a Burbolt, which sticks at this hour up to the Feathers in my heart. Now my request is, to send one of thy what d'ye call 'ems, either to pluck that out, or stick another as fast in hers. Do, and here's my hand, I am thine for three lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: We shall have sport. Thou art in love with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: Up to the very hilts, Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: And thou'ldst have me make her love thee too.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: I think she'll prove a VVitch in earnest. Yes, I could finde in my heart to strike her three quarters deep in love with me too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: But dost thou think that I can do't, and I alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: Truely, Mother Witch, I do verily believe so: and when I see it done, I shall be half perswaded so too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: It's enough. VVhat Art can do, be sure of: turn to the West, and whatsoe'er thou hearest or seest, stand silent, and be not afraid.
SP.STAGE: Enter the Dog; he fawns and leaps upon her.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: Afraid, Mother Witch? turn my face to the West? I said I should always have a back-friend of her; and now it's out. And her little Devil should be hungry, come sneaking behinde me, like a cowardly Catchpole, and clap his Talents on my Haunches. 'Tis woundy cold sure. I dudder and shake like an Aspen-leaf e∣very joynt of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: How now, my Son, how is't?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: Scarce in a clean life, Mother Witch. But did your Gobblin and you spout Latine together?

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: A kinde of Charm I work by. Didst thou hear me?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P:
I heard I know not the Devil what mumble in a scurvy
base tone, like a Drum that had taken cold in the head the last Muster. Very comfortable words: what were they? and who taught them you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: A great learned Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: Learned Man? learned Devil it was as soon? But what? what comfortable news about the Party?

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: Who? Kate Carter? I'll tell thee, thou knowst the Style at the West-end of thy Father's Pease-Field, be there to morrow∣night after Sun-set; and the first live thing thou seest, be sure to follow, and that shall bring thee to thy Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: In the Pease-field? Has she a minde to Codlings al∣ready? The first living thing I meet, you say, shall bring me to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: To a sight of her, I mean. She will seem wantonly coy, and flee thee: but follow her close, and boldly: do but embrace her in thy arms once, and she is thine own.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Bank.
SP.P: At the Style, at the West-end of my Father's Pease∣land, the first live thing I see, follow and embrace her, and she shall be thine. Nay, and I come to embracing once, she shall be mine; I'll go neer to make at Eaglet else.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: A ball well bandied: now the set 's half won:
The Father's wrong I'll wreak upon the Son.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: How now Gentlemen, cloudy? I know Mr. Warbeck, you are in a fog about my Daughters marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: And can you blame me, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: Nor you me justly. VVedding and hanging are tied up both in a Proverb; and Destiny is the Juggler that unties the knot. My hope is, you are reserved to a richer fortune then my poor Daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: However, your promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: Is a kinde of debt, I confess it.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: VVhich honest men should pay.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: Yet some Gentlemen break in that point, now and then, by your leave, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.P: I confess thou hast had a little wrong in the VVench: but patience is the onely salve to cure it. Since Thorney has won the VVench, he has most reason to wear her.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: Love in this kinde admits no reason to wear her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: Then love's a fool, and what wise man will take exception?

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.P: Come, frolick Ned, were every man master of his own for∣tune, Fate might pick straws; and Destiny go a wool-gathering.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.P: You hold yours in a string though. 'Tis well: but if there be any equity, look thou to meet the like usage e're long.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.P: In my love to her Sister Katherine? Indeed, they are a pair of Arrows drawn out of one Quiver, and should flie at an even length, if she do run after her Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.P: Look for the same mercy at my hands, as I have received at thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.P: She'll keep a surer compass. I have too strong a confi∣dence to mistrust her.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.P: And that confidence is a winde, that has blown many a married Man ashore at Cuckolds Haven, I can tell you: I wish yours more prosperous though.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: VVhate're you wish, I'll master my promise to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: Yes, as you did to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: No more of that, if you love me. But for the more as∣surance, the next offer'd occasion shall consummate the Marriage: and that once seal'd,

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.P: Leave the mannage of the rest to my care. But see, the Bridegroom and Bride comes; the new pair of Sheffeild-Knives fitted both to one sheath.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.P: The Sheath might have been better fitted, if some body had their due. But—

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: No harsh language, if thou lovest me. Frank Thorney has done—

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.P: No more then I, or thou, or any man, things so standing, would have attempted.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: Good morrow Mr. Bridegroom.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.P: Come, give thee joy. Mayst thou live long and happy in thy fair choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.P: I thank yee Gentlemen. Kinde Mr. Warbeck, I find you loving.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: Thorney, that creature, (much good do thee with her)
Vertue and beauty hold fair mixture in her.
She's rich no doubt in both. Yet were she fairer,
Thou art right worthy of her. Love her, Thorney,
'Tis nobleness in thee, in her but duty.
The match is fair and equal: the success
I leave to censure. Farewel, Mrs. Bride:
Till now elected, thy old scorne deride.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: Good, Mr. Thorney.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: Nay, you shall not part till you see the Barrels run a-tilt, Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: VVhy change you your face, sweet-Heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: VVho? I? For nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: Dear, say not so: a Spirit of your constancy cannot endure his change for nothing. I have observ'd strange variations in you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: In me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: In you, Sir. Awake: you seem to dream, and in your sleep ou utter sudden and distracted accents, like one at enmity with eace. Dear loving Husband, if I may dare to challenge any nterest in you, give me the reason fully: you may trust my brest as afely as your own.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: VVith what? you half amaze me, prithee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: Come, you shall not; indeed, you shall not shut me from partaking the least dislike that grieves you. I am all yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: And I all thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: You are not, if you keep the least grief from me: but I find the cause; it grew from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: From you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: From some distaste in me or my behaviour: you are not kinde in the concealment. 'Las, Sir, I am young, silly, and plain; more strange to those contents a wife should offer. Say but in what I fail, I'll study satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Come, in nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: I know I do. Knew I as well in what, you should not long be sullen. Prithee Love, if I have been immodest or too bold, speak't in a frown: if peevishly too nice, shew't in a smile. Thy liking is the glass by which I'll habit my behaviour.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Wherefore dost weep now?

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: You, Sweet, have the power to make me passionate as an April-day: now smile, then weep; now pale, then crimson red. You are the powerful Moon of my bloods Sea, to make it ebb or flow into my face, as your looks change.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Change thy conceit, I prithee:
Thou art all perfection: Diana her self
Swells in thy thoughts, and moderates thy beauty.
VVithin thy left eye amorous Cupid fits
Feathering Love-shafts, whose golden heads he dip'd
—In thy chaste brest. In the other lies
Blushing Adonis scarft in modesties.
And still as wanton Cupid blows Love-fires,
Adonis quenches our unchaste desires.
And from these two I briefly do imply
A perfect Embleme of thy modesty.
Then, prithee Dear, maintain no more dispute,
For where thou speakst, it's fit all tongues be mute.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Come, come, those golden strings of flattery
Shall not tie up my speech, Sir; I must know
The ground of your disturbance.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Then look here;
For here, here is the fen in which this Hydra
Of discontent grows rank.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Heaven sheild it: where?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Tho.
SP.L: In mine own bosom: here the cause has root;
The poysoned Leeches twist about my heart,
And will, I hope, confound me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: You speak Riddles.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Tho.
SP.L: Take't plainly then: 'twas told me by a woman
Known and approv'd in Palmestry,
I should have two wives.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: Two wives? Sir, I take it exceeding likely. But let not conceit hurt you: you are afraid to bury me?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: No, no, my Winnifride.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: How say you? Winnifride? you forget me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: No, I forget my self, Susan.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: In what?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Talking of wives, I pretend Winnifride,
A Maid that at my Mothers waited on me
Before thy self.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: I hope, Sir, she may live to take my place. But why should all this move you?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.P: The poor Girl, she has't before thee, and that's the Fiend torments me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: Yet why should this raise mutiny within you? such presages prove often false: or say it should be true?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: That I should have another wife?

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Yes, many; if they be good, the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Never any equal to thee in goodness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Sir, I could wish I were much better for you;
Yet if I knew your fate
Ordain'd you for another, I could wish
(So well I love you, and your hopeful pleasure)
Me in my grave, and my poor vertues added
To my successor.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thorn.
SP.P: Pritheee, prithe, talk not of death or graves; thou rt so rare a goodness, as Death would rather put it self to death, hen murther thee. But we, as all things else, are mutable and hanging.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: Yet you still move in your first sphere of discontent. Sweet, chase those clouds of sorrow, and shine cleerly on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: At my return I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Return? ah me! will you then leave me?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.P: For a time I must: but how? as Birds their young, or loving Bees their Hives, to fetch home richer dainties.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: Leave me? Now has my fear met its effect. You shall not, cost it my life, you shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Why? your reason?

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: Like to the Lap-wing have you all this while with your false love deluded me? pretending counterfeit senses for your dis∣content, and now at last it is by chance stole from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: What? what by chance?

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: Your pre-appointed meeting of single combate with young Warbeck.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Hah!

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: Even so: dissemble not; 'tis too apparent. Then in his look I read it: deny it not; I see't apparent: cost it my undoing, and unto that my life, I will not leave you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Not until when?

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Till he and you be Friends.
Was this your cunning? and then flam me off
With an old VVitch, two VVives, and Winnifride?
Y'are not so kinde indeed as I imagin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: And you more fond by far then I expected.
It is a vertue that attends thy kinde.
But of our business within: and by this kiss,
I'll anger thee no more; troth Chuck I will not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: You shall have no just cause,

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Dear Sue, I shall not.

SP.P: NAy, Cuddy, prithee do not leave us now: if we part all this night, we shall not meet before day.

SP.L: I prithee, Banks, let's keep together now.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: If you were wise, a word would serve: but as you are, I must be forc'd to tell you again, I have a little private business, an hours work; it may prove but an half hours, as luck may serve; and then I take horse and along with you. Have we e're a Witch in the Morice?
No, no; no womans part, but Maid-marian, and the Hobby-horse.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.L: I'll have a Witch; I love a Witch.

SP.P: Faith, VVitches themselves are so common now a days, that the counterfeit will not be regarded. They say we have three or four in Edmonton, besides Mother Sawyer.

SP.L: I would she would dance her part with us.

SP.P: So would not I; for if she comes, the Devil and all comes along with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: VVell, I'll have a Witch: I have lov'd a VVitch ever since I play'd at Cherry-pit. Leave me, and get my horse dress'd: give him Oats; but water him not till I come. VVhither do we foot it first?

SP.L: To Sir Arthur Clarington's first, then whither thou wilt.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: VVell, I'am content: but we must up to Carter's, the rich Yeoman. I must be seen on Hobby-horse there.
O, I smell him now: I'll lay my ears Banks is in love, and that's the reason he would walk melancholy by himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.L: Hah! who was that said I was in love?
Not I.
Not I.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Go to: no more of that. When I understand what you speak, I know what you say: believe that.
VVell, 'twas I, I'll not deny it: I meant no hurt in't. I have seen you walk up to Carter's of Chessum. Banks, were not you there last Shrovetide?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.L: Yes, I was ten days together there the last Shrovetide.

SP.P: How could that be, when there are but seven dayes in the week?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Prithee peace, I reckon stila nova, as a Traveller: thou understandest as a fresh-water Farmer, that never sawest a week beyond Sea. Ask any Souldier that ever received his pay but in the Low Countries, and he'll tell thee there are eight days in the week there, hard by. How dost thou think they rise in high Ger∣many, Italy, and those remoter places?

SP.L: I, but simply there are but seven days in the week yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: No, simply as thou understandest. Prithee, look but in the Lover's Almanack, when he has been but three days absent; Oh, says he, I have not seen my Love these seven yeets: there's a long cut. When he comes to her again, and embraces her, O, says he, now methinks I am in Heaven; and that's a pretty step: he that can get up to Heaven in ten days, need not repent his journey. You may ride a hundred days in a Caroch, and be further off then when you set forth. But I pray you, good Morrice-mates, now leave me. I will be with you by midnight.
Well, since he will be alone, we'll back again, and trouble him no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: But remember, Banks.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: The Hobby-horse shall be remembred. But hark you: get Poldavis, the Barber's Boy for the Witch; because he can shew his Art better then another.

Well, now to my walk. I am neer the place where I should meet
I know not what: say I meet a Thief, I must follow him, if to the Gallows: say I meet a Horse, or Hare, or Hound, still I must follow; some slow-pac'd Beast, I hope: yet Love is full of light∣ness in the heaviest Lovers. Ha! my Guide is come. A VVater-Dog. I am thy first man, Sculler: I go with thee: ply no other but my self: away with the Boat: land me but at Katherine's Dock, my sweet Katherine's Dock, and I'll be a Fare to thee. That way? nay, which way thou wilt, thou know'st the way better then I. Fine gentle Cur it is, and well brought up, I warrant him. VVe go a ducking, Spaniel; thou shalt fetch me the Ducks, pretty kinde Rascal.
SP.STAGE: Enter Spirit in shape of Katherine, vizarded, and takes it off.

SP.SPEAKER: Spir.
SP.L: Thus throw I off mine own essential horror,
And take the shape of a sweet lovely Maid
Whom this Fool doats on. VVe can meet his folly,
But from his Vertues must be Run-aways.
We'll sport with him: but when we reckoning call,
We know where to receive: th' Witch pays for all.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: I? is that the watch-word? She's come. Well, if ever we be married, it shall be at Barking-Church, in memory of thee. Now come behinde, kinde Cur.
SP.L: And have I met thee, sweet Kate?
I will teach thee to walk so late.
SP.P: O see, we meet in Metre. What? dost thou trip from me? Oh that I were upon my Hobby-horse, I would mount after thee so nimble. Stay, Nymph, stay, Nymph, sing'd Apollo: tarry and kiss me; sweet Nymph stay: tarry and kiss me, Sweet. We will to Chessum-street, and then to the house stands in the high-way. Nay, by your leave, I must embrace you. Oh help, help, I am drown'd, I am drown'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: This was an ill night to go a wooing in; I finde it now in Pond' Almanack: thinking to land at Katherine's Dock, I was almost at Gravesend. I'll never go to a Wench in the Dog-days again; yet 'tis cool enough. Had you never a paw in this Dog-trick? a mangie take that black hide of yours: I'll throw you in at Limehouse in some Tanner's Pit or other.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: How now? who's that laughs at me? Hist to him. [Dog braks.] Peace, peace; thou didst but thy kinde neither. 'Twas my own fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Take heed how thou trustest the Devil another time.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: How now? who's that speaks? I hope you have not your reading Tongue about you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Yes, I can speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: The Devil you can. You have read Esop's Fables then: I have play'd one of your parts then; the Dog that catch'd at the shadow in the water. Pray you, let me catechize you a little: VVhat might one call your name, Dog?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: My Dame calls me Tom.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: 'Tis well; and she may call me Ass: so there's an whole one betwixt us, Tom-Ass. She said, I should follow you, indeed. VVell, Tom, give me thy fist; we are Friends: you shall be mine Ingle: I love you; but I pray you let's have no more of these ducking devices.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: Not, if you love me. Dogs love where they are beloved. Cherish me, and I'll do any thing for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: VVell, you shall have Jowls and Livers: I have Butchets to my Friends that shall bestow 'em: and I will keep Crusts and Bones for you, if you'll be a kinde Dog, Tom.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Any thing: I'll help thee to thy Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Wilt thou? That promise shall cost me a brown Loaf, though I steal it out of my Father's Cupboard. You'll eat stollen Goods, Tom, will you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Oh best of all. The sweetest bits, those.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: You shall not starve, Ningle Tom; believe that, if you love Fish, I'll help you to Maids and Soles. I'm acquainted with a Fishmonger.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Maids and Soles? Oh, sweet bits! Banquetting stuff, those.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: One thing I would request you, Ningle, as you have play'd the Knavish Cur with me a little, that you would mingle amongst our Morrice-Dancers in the morning. You can dance?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: Yes, yes, any thing: I'll be there, but unseen to any but thy self. Get thee gone before: feare not my presence. I have work to night. I serve more Masters, more Dames then one.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.L: He can serve Mammon and the Devil too.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: It shall concern thee, and thy Loves purchase:
There's a gallant Rival loves the Maid;
And likely is to have her. Mark what a mischief
Before the Morrice ends, shall light on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: On sweet Ningle, thy neuse once again. Friends must part for a time: farewel, with this remembrance; shalt have bread too when we meet again. If ever there were an honest Devil, 'twill be the Devil of Edmonton, I see. Farewel Tom. I prithee dog me as soon as thou canst.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: I'll not miss thee, and be merry with thee.
Those that are joys denied, must take delight
In sins and mischiefs, 'tis the Devil's right.
SP.STAGE: Enter Young Thorney, VVinnifride as a Boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Prithee no more: those tears give nourishment
To weeds and briers in me, which shortly will
O'regrow and top my head: my shame will sit
And cover all that can be seen of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: I have not shewn this check in company,
Pardon me now: thus singled with your self,
It calls a thousand sorrows round about.
Some going before, and some on either side;
But infinite behinde: all chain'd together.
Your second adulterous Marriage leads;
That's the sad Eclipse, the effects must follow.
As, plagues of shame, spight, scorn, and obloquy.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Tho.
SP.L: Why? hast thou not left one hours patience
To add to all the rest? One hour bears us
Beyond the reach of all these Enemies.
Are we not now set forward in the flight,
Provided with the Dowry of my sin,
To keep us in some other Nation?
VVhile we together are, we are at home
In any place.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: 'Tis fowl ill gotten coyn,
Far worse then Usury or Extortion.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Let my Father then make the restitution,
VVho forc'd me take the bribe: it is his gift
And patrimony to me; so I receive it.
He would not bless, not look a Father on me,
Until I satisfied his angry will.
VVhen I was sold, I sold my self again
(Some Knaves have done't in Lands, and I in Body)
For money, and I have the hire. But, sweet, no more,
'Tis hazard of discovery, our discourse;
And then prevention takes off all our hopes.
For only but to take her leave of me,
My VVife is coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: VVho coming? your VVife?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Tho.
SP.L: No, no, thou art here: the woman; I knew
Not how to call her now: but after this day
She shall be quite forgot, and have no name
In my remembrance. See, see, she's come.
Co lead the horses to the hills top, there I'll meet thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Nay, with your favour, let him stay a little.
I would part with him too, because he is
Your sole Companion; and I'll begin with him,
Reserving you the last.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: I, with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: You may hear, if it please you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: No, 'tis not fit.
Some rudiments, I conceive, they must be,
To overlook my slippery footings. And so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: No, indeed, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Tush, I know it must be so, and 'tis necessary.
On, but be brief.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: VVhat charge so'ere you lay upon me, Mistress,
I shall support it faithfully (being honest)
To my best strength.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Believe 't shall be no other. I know you were
Commended to my husband by a noble Knight.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Oh Gods! Oh, mine eyes!

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: How now? what ailst thou, Lad?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Something hit mine eye, it makes it water still,
Even as you said, Commended to my Husband.
Some door I think it was. I was, forsooth,
Commended to him by Sir Arthr Clarington.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: VVhose Servant once my Thorney was himself.
That title methinks should make you almost Fellows,
Or at the least much more then a Servant;
And I am sure he will respect you so.
Your love to him then needs no spur for me,
And what for my sake you will ever do;
'Tis fit it should be bought with something more
Then fair entreats. Look here's a Jewel for thee,
A pretty wanton Label for thine ear;
And I would have it hang there, still to whisper
These words to thee, Thou hast my Jewel with thee.
It is but earnest of a larger bounty,
VVhen thou returnst, with praises of thy service,
VVhich I am confident thou wilt deserve.
VVhy, thou art many now, besides thy self:
Thou maist be Servant, Friend, and VVife to him.
A good VVife is then all. A Friend can play
The VVife and Servants part, and shift enough.
No less the Servant can the Friend and Wife.
'Tis all but sweet society, good counsel,
Enterchang'd loves; yes, and counsel-keeping.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Not done yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Even now, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Mistress, believe my vow, your severe eye
VVere it present to command; your bounteous hand,
VVere it then by to buy or bribe my service,
Shall not make me more dear or neer unto him,
Then I shall voluntary. I'll be all your charge,
Servant, Friend, VVife to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: VVilt thou?
Now blessings go with thee for't: courtesies
Shall meet thee coming home.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Pray you say plainly, Mistress,
Are you jealous of him? if you be,
I'll look to him that way too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Sayst thou so?
I would thou hadst a womans bosom now.
VVe have weak thoughts within us. Alas,
There's nothing so strong in us as suspicion:
But I dare not, nay, I will not think
So hardly of my Thorney.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Believe it, Mistress,
I'll be no Pander to him; and if I finde
Any loose lubrick scapes in him, I'll watch him,
And at my return, protest I'll shew you all.
He shall hardly offend without my knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Thine own diligence is that I press,
And not the curious eye over his faults.
Farewel: if I should never see thee more,
Take it for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Prithee take that along with thee,
And haste thee to the hills top; I'll be there instantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: No haste I prithee, slowly as thou canst.
Pray let him obey me now: 'tis happily his last
Service to me. My power is e'en a going out of sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Why would you delay? we have no other
Business now but to part.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: And will not that, sweet heart, ask a long time?
Methinks it is the hardest piece of work
That e're I took in hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Fie, fie, why look,
I'll make it plain and easie to you: Farewel.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Ah, 'las! I am not half perfect in it yet.
I must have it read over an hundred times.
Pray you take some pains, I confess my dulness.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: What a Thorne this Rose grows on? parting were sweet.
But what a trouble 'twill be to obtain it?
Come, again and again, farewel. Yet wilt return?
All questions of my journey, my stay, imployment,
And revisitation, fully I have answered all.
There's nothing now behinde, but nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: And that nothing is more hard then any thing,
Then all the every things. This Request.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: What is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: That I may bring you through one pasture more
Up to you knot of trees: amongst those shadows
I'll vanish from you, they shall teach me how.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: VVhy, 'tis granted: come, walk then.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Nay, not too fast.
They say slow things have best perfection:
The gentle showre wets to fertility.
The churlish storm may mischief with his bounty.
The baser beasts take strength, even from the womb:
But the Lord Lion's whelp is feeble long.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Now for an early mischief and a sudden:
The minde's about it now. One touch from me
Soon sets the body forward.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Your request is out: yet will you leave me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: VVhat? so churlishly? you'll make me stay for ever,
Rather then part with such a sound from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: VVhy you almost anger me. Pray you be gone.
You have no company, and 'tis very early;
Some hurt may betide you homewards.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Tush, I fear none.
To leave you, is the greatest hurt I can suffer:
Besides, I expect your Father and mine own,
To meet me back, or overtake me with you.
They began to stir when I came after you:
I know they'll not be long.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: So, I shall have more trouble.
Thank you for that. Then I'll ease all at once.
'Tis done now: what I ne'er thought on. You shall not go back.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: VVhy? shall I go along with thee? sweet musick!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: No, to a better place.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Any place, I:
I'm there at home, where thou pleasest to have me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: At home? I'll leave you in your last lodging.
I must kill you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Oh fine! you'ld fright me from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.P: You see I had no purpose: I'm unarm'd. 'Tis this minutes decree, and it must be. Look, this will serve your turn.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.P: I'll not turn from it, if you be earst, Sir. Yet you may tell me wherefore you'll kill me.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Because you are a whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: There's one deep wound already: a whore?
'Twas ever further from me then the thought
Of this black hour: a whore?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Yes, I'll prove it,
And you shall confess it. You are my whore,
No wife of mine. The word admits no second.
I was before wedded to another, have her still.
I do not lay the sin unto your charge,
'Tis all mine own. Your marriage was my theft.
For I espous'd your dowry, and I have it:
I did not purpose to have added murther;
The Devil did not prompt me: till this minute
You might have safe returned; now you cannot:
You have dogg'd your own death.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: And I deserve it.
I'm glad my fate was so intelligent.
'Twas some good Spirits motion. Die? oh, 'twas time!
How many yeers might I have slept in sin?
Sin of my most hatred too, Adultery?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Nay, sure 'twas likely that the most was past;
For I meant never to return to you
After this parting.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Why then I thank you more,
You have done lovingly, leaving your self,
That you would thus bestow me on another.
Thou art my Husband, Death, and I embrace thee
With all the love I have. Forget the stain
Of my unwitting sin: and then I come
A Chrystal Virgin to thee. My Soul's purity
Shall with bold Wings ascend the Doors of Mercy;
For Innocence is ever her Companion.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Not yet mortal? I would not linger you,
Or leave you a tongue to blab.

SP.SPEAKER: Sus.
SP.L: Now heaven reward you ne'er the worse for me.
I did not think that death had been so sweet;
Nor I so apt to love him. I could ne'er die better,
Had I staid forty yeers for preparation:
For I'm in charity with all the VVorld.
Let me for once be thine example, Heaven;
Do to this man as I him free forgive.
And may he better die, and better live.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Tho.
SP.L: 'Tis done; and I am in: once past our height,
We scorn the deepst Abyss. This follows now,
To heal her VVounds by dressing of the VVeapon:
Arms, thighs, hands, any place; we must not fail,
Light scratches giving such deep ones. The best I can
To binde my self to this Tree. Now's the storm,
Which if blown o're, many fair days may follow.
So, so, I'm fast; I did not think I could
Have done so well behinde me. How prosperous
And effectual mischief sometimes is? Help, help;
Murther, murther, murther.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: Ha! VVhom tolls the Bell for?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Oh, oh!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: Ah me! the cause appears too soon: my Child, my Son.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: Susan, Girl, Child. Not speak to thy Father? Hah!

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Tho.
SP.L: O lend me some assistance to o'retake this hapless woman.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.P: Let's o'retake the murtherers. Speak whilst thou canst; anon may be too late. I fear thou hast deaths mark upon thee too.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: I know them both; yet such an Oath is pass'd,
As pulls damnation up if it be broke;
I dare not name 'em: think what forc'd men do.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.P: Keep oath with murtherers? that were a conscience to hold the Devil in.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: Nay, Sir, I can describe 'em;
Shall shew them as familiar as their names.
The Taller of the two at this time wears
His Satten-doublet white, but Crimson lin'd;
Hose of black Satten, Cloak of Scarlet.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: Warbeck, Warbeck, Warbeck: Do you list to this, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: Yes, yes, I listen you: here's nothing to be heard.

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.P: Th' others Cloak branch'd Velvet black, Velvet lin'd his Suit.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: I have 'em already: Somerton, Somerton.
Binal revenge, all this. Come, Sir, the first work
Is to pursue the Murtherers, when we have remov'd
These mangled bodies hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: Sir, take that Carcase there, and give me this.
I'll not own her now; she's none of mine.
Bob me off with a dumb shew? No, I'll have life.
This is my Son too, and while there's life in him,
'Tis half mine; take you halfe that silence for 't.
VVhen I speak, I look to be spoken to: forgetful Slut?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: Alas! what grief may do now?
Look, Sir, I'll take this load of sorrow with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: I, do, and I'll hre this. How do you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Y. Thor.
SP.L: O, very ill, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: Yes, I think so; but 'tis well you can speak yet.
There's no musick but in sound, sound it must be.
I have not wept these twenty yeers before,
And that I guess was e're that Girl was born:
Yet now methinks, if I but knew the way,
My heart's so full, I could weep night and day.
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir Arthur Clarington, Warbeck, Somerton.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Come, Gentlemen, we must all help to grace
The nimble-footed youth of Edmonton, that are so kinde
To call us up to day with an high Morrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: I could wish it for the best, it were the worst now.
Absurditie's in my opinion ever the best Dancer in a Morrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: I could rather sleep then see 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Not well, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: Faith not ever thus leaden; yet I know no cause for 't.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.P: Now am I beyond mine own condition highly dispos'd to mirth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Well, you may have yet a Morrice to help both;
To strike you in a dump, and make him merry.
SP.STAGE: Enter Fidler and Morrice; all but Banks.

SP.SPEAKER: Fidl.
SP.P: Come, will you set your selves in Morrice-ray? the fore-Bell, second Bell, Tenor and great Bell; Maid-marion for the same Bell. But where's the Weather-cock now? the Hobby-horse?

SP.L: Is not Banks come yet? What a spight 'tis?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: When set you forward, Gentlemen?

SP.P: VVe stay but for the Hobby-horse, Sir: all our Footmen are ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: 'Tis marvel your Horse should be behinde your Foot.
Yes, Sir: he goes further about: we can come in at the
VVicket, but the broad Gate must be opened for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Oh, we staid for you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Onely my Horse wanted a Shooe, Sir: but we shall make you amends e're we part.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: I? well said, make 'em drink e're they begin.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P:
A bowl, I prithee, and a little for my Horse, [with beer.
he'll mount the better. Nay, give me, I must drink to him, he'll not pledge else. Here Hobby. [Holds him the bowl.] I pray you: No? not drink? You see, Gentlemen, we can but bring our horse to the VVater; he may chuse whether he'll drink or no.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: A good Moral made plain by History.
Strike up, Father Sawgut, strike up.

SP.SPEAKER: Fidl.
SP.P: E'en when you will, Children. Now in the name of the best foot forward. How now? not a word in thy Guts? I think, Children, my Instrument has caught cold on the sudden.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.L: My Ningle's knavery: black Tom's doing.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Why what mean you, Father Sawgut?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Why what would you have him do? You hear his Fid∣dle is speechless.

SP.SPEAKER: Fidl.
SP.P: I'll lay mine Ear to my Instrument, that my poor Fiddle is bewitch'd. I play'd The Flowers in May, e'en now, as sweet as a Violet; now 'twill not go against the hair: you see I can make no more Musick then a Beetle of a Cow-turd.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Let me see, Father Sawgut, say, once you had a brave Hob∣by-horse, that you were beholding to. I'll play and dance too. Ningle, away with it.
SP.STAGE: [Dog plays the Morrice; which ended, enter a Constable and Officers.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: I marry, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.L: Away with jollity, 'tis too sad an hour.
Sir Arthur Clarington, your own assistance,
In the Kings Name, I charge, for apprehension
Of these two Murderers, Warbeck and Somerton.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Ha! flat Murtherers?

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha, this has awakened my melancholy.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: And struck my mirth down flat. Murtherers?

SP.SPEAKER: Const.
SP.L: The accusation is flat against you, Gentlemen.
Sir, you may be satisfied with this. I hope
You'll quietly obey my power;
'Twill make your cause the fairer.

SP.SPEAKER: Ambo.
SP.L: Oh! with all our hearts, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P:
There's my Rival taken up for Hang-man's meat. Tom told me he was about a piece of Villany. Mates and Morrice∣men, you see here's no longer piping, no longer dancing. This news of Murder has slain the Morrice. You that go the foot∣way,
fare ye well: I am for a Gallop. Come, Ningle.

SP.SPEAKER: Fidl.
SP.P: [Strikes his Fiddle.] I? Nay and my Fiddle be come to himself again, I care not. I think the Devil has been abroad amongst us to day. I'll keep thee out of thy fit now if I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: These things are full of horror, full of pity.
But if this time be constant to the proof,
The guilt of both these Gentlemen I dare take
Upon mine own danger; yet howsoever, Sir,
Your power must be obey'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: Oh most willingly, Sir.
'Tis a most sweet affliction. I could not meet
A joy in the best shape with better will.
Come, fear not, Sir; nor Judge, nor Evidence,
Can binde him o're, who's freed by conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: Mine stands so upright to the middle Zone,
It takes no shadow to't, it goes alone.

SP.STAGE: Enter Old Banks, and two or three Country-men.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.P: MY Horse this morning runs most pitiously of the Glaunders, whose nose yesternight was as clean as any Man's here now coming from the Barbers; and this I'll take my death upon 'tis long of this Jadish Witch, Mother Sawyer.

I took my Wife and a Servingman in our Town of Edmonton, thrashing in my Barn together, such Corn as Country-VVenches carry to Market; and examining my Polecat why she did so, she swore in her conscience she was bewitch'd: and what Witch have we about us, but Mother Sawyer?
Rid the Town of her, else all our Wives will do nothing else but dance al out other Country May-poles.
Our Cattel fall, our Wives fall, our Daughters fall, and Maid-servants fall; and we our selves shall not be able to stand, if this Beast be suffered to graze amongst us.
SP.STAGE: Enter W. Hamlac, with Thatch and a Link.

SP.SPEAKER: Haml.
SP.L: Burn the Witch, the Witch, the Witch, the Witch.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: What hast got there?

SP.SPEAKER: Haml.
SP.P: A handful of Thatch pluck'd off a Hovel of hers: and they say, when 'tis burning, if she be a VVitch, she'll come run∣ning in.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.P: Fire it, fire it: I'll stand between thee and home for any danger.
SP.STAGE: As that burns, enter the Witch.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: Diseases, Plagues; the curse of an old VVoman follow and fall upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Are you come, you old Trot?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.L: You hot VVhore, must we fetch you with fire in your tail?
This Thatch is as good as a Jury to prove she is a Witch.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Out Witch; beat her, kick her, set fire on her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Shall I be murthered by a bed of Serpents? help, help!
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir Arthur Clarington, and a Justice.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Hang her, beat her, kill her.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: How now? Forbear this violence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: A crew of Villains, a knot of bloody Hang-men set to torment me I know not why.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: Alas, neighbour Banks, are you a Ring-leader in mischief:
Fie, to abuse an aged woman!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.P: VVoman? a She-hell-cat, a Witch: to prove her one, we no sooner set fire on the Thatch of her House, but in she came running, as if the Divel had sent her in a Barrel of Gun-powder; which trick as surely proves her a VVitch, as the Pox in a snuffling nose, is a sign a Man is a Whore-master.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Come, come; firing her Thatch? ridiculous: take heed Sirs what you do: unless your proofs come better arm'd, instead of turning her into a VVitch, you'll prove your selves starke Fools.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Fools?

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: Arrant Fools.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.P: Pray, Mr. Justice what do you call 'em, hear me but in one thing: This grumbling Devil owes me I know no good will ever since I fell out with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: And brakedst my back with beating me.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.L: I'll break it worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: VVilt thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: You must not threaten her: 'tis against Law. Go on.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.P: So, Sir, ever since, having a Dun-Cow tied up in my Back-side, let me go thither, or but cast mine eye at her, and if I should be hang'd, I cannot chuse, though it be ten times in an hour, but run to the Cow, and taking up her tail, kiss (saving your Worship's Reverence) my Gow behinde; That the whole Town of Edmonton has been ready to be-piss themselves with laughing me to scorn.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: And this is long of her?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.P: VVho the Devil else? for is any man such an Ass, to be such a Baby, if he were not bewitch'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.P: Nay, if she be a VVitch, and the harms she does end in such sports, she may scape burning.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Go, go; pray vex her not: she is a Subject, and you must not be Judges of the Law to strike her as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: No, no, we'll finde cudgel enough to strike her.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.L: I, no lips to kiss but my Cows—?

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Rots and foul maladies eat up thee and thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Here's none now, Mother Sawyer, but this Gentleman, my self and you; let us to some milde Questions, have you milde Answers? Tell us honestly, and with a free confession, (we'll do our best to wean you from it) are you a VVitch, or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: I am none.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: Be not so furious.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
