SP.P: I am none. None but base Curs so bark at me. I am none. Or would I were: if every poor old VVoman be trod on thus by staves, revil'd, kick'd, beaten, as I am daily, she to be re∣veng'd had need turn VVitch.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: And you to be reveng'd have sold your Soul to th'Devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Keep thine own from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: You are too sawcie, and too bitter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: Sawcie? by what commission can he send my Soul on the Divel's Errand, more then I can his? is he a Landlord of my Soul, to thrust it when he list out of door?

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: Know whom you speak to.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: A Man: perhaps, no Man. Men in gay clothes, whose Backs are laden with Titles and Honours, are within far more crooked then I am; and if I be a VVitch, more VVitch-like.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.P: Y' are a base Hell-hound. And now, Sir, let me tell you, Far and neer she's bruited for a woman that maintains a Spirit that sucks her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: I defie thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Arth.
SP.P: Go, go, I can, if need be, bring an hundred voyces e'en here in Edmonton, that shall lowd proclaim thee for a secret and pernicious Witch.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: Do you laugh? why laugh you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: At my name: the brave name this Knight gives me, Witch.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: Is the Name of Witch so pleasing to thine Ear?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Pray, Sir, give way, and let her Tongue gallop on.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: A Witch? who is not?
Hold not that universal Name in scorne then.
What are your painted things in Princes Courts?
Upon whose Eye-lids Lust sits blowing fires
To burn Mens Souls in sensual hot desires:
Upon whose naked Paps, a Leachers thought
Acts Sin in fouler shapes then can be wrought.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: But those work not as you do.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: No, but far worse:
These, by Inchantments, can whole Lordships change
To Trunks of rich Attire: turn Ploughs and Teams
To Flanders Mares and Coaches; and huge trains
Of servitors, to a French Butter-Flie.
Have you not City-witches who can turn
Their husbands wares, whole standing shops of wares,
To sumptuous Tables, Gardens of stoln sin?
In one yeer wasting, what scarce twenty win.
Are not these Witches?

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: Yes, yes, but the Law
Casts not an eye on these.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: VVhy then on me,
Or any lean old Beldame? Reverence once
Had wont to wait on age. Now an old woman
Ill favour'd grown with yeers, if she be poor,
Must be call'd Bawd or VVitch. Such so abus'd
Are the course VVitches: t'other are the fine,
Spun for the Devil's own wearing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: And so is thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: She on whose tongue a whirlwind sits to blow
A man out of himself, from his soft pillow,
To lean his head on Rocks and fighting waves,
Is not that Scold a Witch? The Man of Law
VVhose honeyed hopes the credulous Client draws,
(As Bees by tinkling Basons) to swarm to him,
From his own Hive, to work the VVax in his;
He is no VVitch, not he.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: But these Men-VVitches
Are not in trading with Hells Merchandize,
Like such as you are, that for a word, a look,
Denial of a Coal of fire, kill Men,
Children and Cattel.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Tell them, Sir, that do so:
Am I accus'd for such an one?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Yes, 'twill be sworn.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Dare any swear I ever tempted Maiden
VVith golden hooks flung at her chastity,
To come and lose her honour? and being lost,
To pay not a Denier for't? Some slaves have done it.
Men-witches can without the Fangs of Law,
Drawing once one drop of blood, put counterfeit pieces
Away for true Gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: By one thing she speaks,
I know now she's a VVitch, and dare no longer
Hold conference with the Fury.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: Let's then away:
Old woman, mend thy life, get home and pray.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: For his confusion. [Enter Dog.] My dear Tom-boy welcome.
SP.L: I am torn in pieces by a pack of Curs
Clap'd all upon me, and for want of thee:
Comfort me: thou shalt have the Teat anon.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Bough wough: I'll have it now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: I am dri'd up
VVith cursing and with madness; and have yet
No blood to moysten these sweet lips of thine.
Stand on thy hind-legs up. Kiss me, my Tommy,
And rub away some wrinkles on my brow,
By making my old ribs to shrug for joy
Of thy fine tricks. VVhat hast thou done? Let's tickle.
Hast thou struck the horse lame as I bid thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Yes, and nip'd the sucking-childe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Ho, ho, my dainty,
My little Pearl. No Lady loves her Hound,
Monkey, or Parakeet, as I do thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: The Maid has been churming Butter nine hours; but it shall not come.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Let 'em eat Cheese and choak.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: I had rare sport
Among the Clowns i'th' Morrice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: I could dance
Out of my skin to hear thee. But my Curl-pare,
That Jade, that foul-tongu'd whore, Nan Ratcliff,
VVho for a little Soap lick'd by my Sow,
Struck, and almost had lam'd it; Did not I charge thee,
To pinch that Quean to th' heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Bough, wough, wough: Look here else.

SP.SPEAKER: Ratc.
SP.P: See, see, see; the Man i'th' Moon has built a new Wind-mill, and what running there's from all quarters of the City to learn the Art of Grinding!

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Ho, ho, ho! I thank thee, my sweet Mungrel.

SP.SPEAKER: Ratc.
SP.P: Hoyda! a-pox of the Devil's false Hopper! all the gol∣den Meal runs into the rich Knaves purses, and the poor have no∣thing but Bran. Hey derry down! Are not you Mother Sawyer?

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: No, I am a Lawyer.

SP.SPEAKER: Ratc.
SP.P: Art thou? I prithee let me scratch thy Face; for thy Pen has flea'd off a great many mens skins. You'll have brave doings in the Vacation; for Knaves and Fools are at variance in every Village. I'll sue Mother Sawyer, and her own Sow shall give in evidence against her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Touch her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ratc.
SP.P: Oh my Ribs are made of a paynd Hose, and they break. There's a Lancashire Horn-pipe in my throat: hark how it tickles it, with Doodle, Doodle, Doodle, Doodle. VVelcome Serjeants: welcome Devil. Hands, hands; hold hands, and dance a-round, a-round, a-round.
SP.STAGE: Enter Old Banks, his Son the Clown, Old Ratcliff, Country-fellows.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Ratc.
SP.L: She's here; alas, my poor wife is here.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.P: Catch her fast, and have her into some close Chamber: do, for she's as many VVives are, stark mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.L: The witch, Mother Sawyer, the witch, the devil. [Car. her off.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Ratc.
SP.L: O my dear VVife! help, Sirs!

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.L: You see your work, Mother Bumby.

SP.SPEAKER: Saw.
SP.L: My work? should she & all you here run mad, is the work mine?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: No, on my conscience, she would not hurt a Devil of two yeers old.
SP.STAGE: Enter Old Ratcliff, and the rest.
SP.L: How now? what's become of her?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Ratc.
SP.P: Nothing: she's become nothing, but the miserable trunk of a wretched woman. We were in her hands as Reeds in a mighty Tempest: spight of our strengths, away she brake; and no∣thing in her mouth being heard, but the Devil, the VVitch, the VVitch, the Devil; she beat out her own brains, and so died.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: It's any Man's case, be he never so wise, to die when his brains go a wool-gathering.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Banks.
SP.P: Masters, be rul'd by me; let's all to a Justice. Hag, thou hast done this, and thou shalt answer it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Banks, I defie thee.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.P: Get a VVarrant first to examine her, then ship her to Newgate: here's enough, if all her other villanies were pardon'd, to burn her for a VVitch. You have a Spirit, they say, comes to you in the likeness of a Dog; we shall see your Cur at one time or other: if we do, unless it be the Devil himself, he shall go how∣ling to the Goal in one chain, and thou in another.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Be hang'd thou in a third, and do thy worst.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: How, Father? you send the poor dumb thing howling to th'Goal? He that makes him howl, makes me roar.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.L: VVhy, foolish Boy, dost thou know him?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: No matter, if I do or not. He's baylable I am sure by Law. But if the Dog's word will not be taken, mine shall.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.L: Thou Bayl for a Dog?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Yes, or a Bitch either, being my Friend. I'll lie by the heels my self, before Puppison shall: his Dog-days are not come yet, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.L: VVhat manner of Dog is it? didst ever see him?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P:
See him? yes, and given him a bone to gnaw twenty times. The Dog is no Court foysting Hound, that fills his belly
full by base wagging his tayl; neither is it a Citizens VVater-Spaniel, enticing his Master to go a-ducking twice or thrice a week, whilst his VVife makes Ducks and Drakes at home: this is no Paris-Garden Bandog neither, that keeps a Bough, wough, woughing, to have Butchers bring their Curs thither; and when all comes to all, they run away like Sheep: neither is this the black Dog of New-gate.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.L: No, Good-man Son-fool, but the Dog of Hell-gate.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.L: I say, Good-man Father-fool, it's a lye.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: He's bewitch'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: A gross lye as big as my self. The Devil in St. Dunstan's will as soon drink with this poor Cur, as with any Temple-Bar-Laundress, that washes and wrings Lawyers.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Bough, wough, wough, wough.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: O the Dog's here, the Dog's here.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.L: It was the voice of a Dog.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: The voice of a Dog? if that voice were a Dog's, what voice had my Mother? so am I a Dog: bough, wough, wough: it was I that bark'd so, Father, to make Cocks-combs of these Clowns.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.P: However, we'll be Cocks-comb'd no longer: away therefore to th' Justice for a Warrant; and then, Gammer Gur∣ton, have at your Needle of VVitch-craft.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: And prick thine own eyes out. Go, peevish Fools.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Ningle, you had like to have spoyl'd all with your Boughings. I was glad to put 'em off with one of my Dog-tricks, on a sudden, I am bewitch'd, little Cost-me-nought, to love thee—a Pox, that Morrice makes me spit in thy mouth. I dare not stay. Fare∣wel, Ningle; you whoreson Dogs-nose. Farewel Witch.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Bough, wough, wough, wough.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: Minde him not, he's not worth thy worrying: run at a fairer Game: that fowl-mouth'd Knight, scurvy Sir Arthur, flie at him, my Tommy; and pluck out's throat.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: No, there a Dog already biting's conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: That's a sure Blood-hound. Come, let's home and play.
Our black work ended, we'll make holiday.

SP.STAGE: Enter Katherine: a Bed thrust forth, on it Frank in a slumber.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: Brother, Brother! So sound a sleep? that's well.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: No, not I, Sister: he that's wounded here,
As I am; (all my other hurts are bitings
Of a poor flea) but he that here once bleeds,
Is maim'd incurably.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: My good sweet Brother,
(For now my Sister must grow up in you)
Though her loss strikes you through, and that I feel
The blow as deep, I pray thee be not cruel
To kill me too, by seeing you cast away
In your own helpless sorrow. Good Love, sit up:
And if you can give Physick to your self,
I shall be well.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I'll do my best.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: I thank you. What do you look about for?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Nothing, nothing; but I was thinking, Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: Dear heart, what?

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Who but a fool would thus be bound to a bed,
Having this Room to walk in?

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: Why do you talk so? would you were fast asleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: No, no, I'm not idle:
But here's my meaning: being rob'd as I am,
VVhy should my Soul, which married was to hers,
Live in divorce, and not flie after her?
VVhy should not I walk hand in hand with death
To finde my Love out?

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: That were well, indeed.
Your time being come, when death is sent to call you,
No doubt you shall meet her.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Why should not I go without calling?

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: Yes, Brother, so you might, were there no place
To go to when y'are gone, but onely this.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Troth, Sister, thou sayst true:
For when a man has been an hundred yeers,
Hard travelling o're the tottering bridge of age,
He's not the thousand part upon his way.
All life is but a wandring to finde home:
When we are gone, we are there. Hapyy were man,
Could here his Voyage end; he should not then
Answer how well or ill he steer'd his Soul,
By Heaven's or by Hell's Compass; how he put in
(Loosing bless'd Goodness shore) at such a sin;
Nor how life's dear provision he has spent:
Nor how far he in's Navigation went
Beyond Commission. This were a fine Raign,
To do ill, and not hear of it again.
Yet then were Man more wretched then a Beast:
For, Sister, our dead pay is sure the best.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: 'Tis so, the best or worst. And I wish Heaven
To pay (and so I know it will) that Traytor,
That Devil Somerton (who stood in mine eye
Once as an Angel) home to his deservings.
What Villain but himself, once loving me,
With Warbeck's Soul would pawn his own to Hell,
To be reveng'd on my poor Sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Slaves! a pair of merciless Slaves!
Speak no more of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.L: I think this talking hurts you.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Does me no good, I'm sure,
I pay for't everywhere.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: I have done then.
Eat, if you cannot sleep: you have these two days
Not tasted any food. Jane, is it ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: What's ready? what's ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: I have made ready a rosted Chicken for you.
Sweet, wilt thou eat?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: A pretty stomach on a sudden—yes—
There's one in the house can play upon a Lute:
Good Girl, let's hear him too.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: You shall, dear Brother.
VVould I were a Musician, you should hear
How I would feast your ear.
Stay, mend your Pillow, and raise you higher.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: I am up too high: am I not, Sister, now?

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: No, no; 'tis well: fall to, fall to. A Knife: here's ne∣ver a Knife, Brother, I'll look out yours.
SP.STAGE: Enter Dog, shrugging as it were for joy, and dances.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Sister, O Sister, I am ill upon a sudden; and can eat no∣thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: In very deed you shall. The want of Food makes you so faint. Ha! here's none in your pocket. I'll go fetch a Knife.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Will you? 'Tis well, all's well.
SP.STAGE: [She gone, he searches first one, then the other Pocket-Knife found. Dog runs off. He lies on one side: the Spirit of Susan his second Wife comes to the Beds-side. He stares at it; and turning to the other side, it's there too. In the mean time, Winnifride as a Page comes in, stands at his Beds-feet sadly: he frighted, sits upright. The Spirit vanishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: What art thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: A lost Creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: So am I too.

SP.SPEAKER: Win?
SP.L: Ah, my She-Page!

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.P: For your sake I put on a shape that's false; yet do I wear a heart true to you as your own.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: VVould mine and thine were Fellows in one house. Kneel by me here: on this side now? How dar'st thou come to mock me on both sides of my bed?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: VVhen?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: But just now: out-face me, stare upon me with strange postures: turn my Soul wilde by a face in which were drawn a thou∣sand Ghosts leap'd newly from their Graves, to pluck me into a winding-Sheet.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.P: Believe it, I came no neerer to you then you place, at your beds-feet; and of the house had leave, calling my self your Horse∣boy, in to come, and visit my sick Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Then 'twas my Fancy. Some Wind-mill in my brains for want of sleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: VVould I might never sleep, so you could rest.
But you have pluck'd a Thunder on your head.
VVhose noise cannot cease suddainly: why should you
Dance at the wedding of a second wife?
VVhen scarce the Musick which you heard at mine
Had tane a farewel of you. O this was ill!
And they who thus can give both hands away,
In th' end shall want their best Limbs.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Winnifride, the Chamber door fast?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Sit thee then down;
And when th'ast heard me speak, melt into tears:
Yet I to save those eyes of thine from weeping,
Being to write a Story of us two,
In stead of Ink, dip'd my sad Pen in blood.
VVhen of thee I took leave, I went abroad
Onely for Pillage, as a Freebooter,
VVhat Gold soere I got, to make it thine.
To please a Father, I have Heaven displeas'd.
Striving to cast two wedding Rings in one,
Through my bad workmanship I now have none.
I have lost her and thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: I know she's dead: but you have me still.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Nay, her this hand murdered; and so I lose thee too.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Oh me!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Be quiet, for thou my evidence art,
Jurie and Judge: sit quiet, and I'll tell all.
SP.STAGE: As they whisper, enter at one end o'th' Stage Old Carter and Katharine, Dog at th' other, pawing softly at Frank.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: I have run madding up and down to find you, being laden with the heaviest News that ever poor Daughter carried.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: VVhy? is the Boy dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: Dead, Sir! O Father, we are cozen'd: you are told the Mur∣therer sings in Prison, and he laughs here.
SP.L: This Villaine kil'd my Sister: see else, see,
A bloody Knife in's Pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: Bless me, patience!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: The Knife, the Knife, the Knife!

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: VVhat Knife?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: To cut my Chicken up, my Chicken; be you my Car∣ver, Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: That I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: How the Devil steels our brows after doing ill!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: My stomack and my sight are taken from me; all is not well within me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: I believe thee, Boy: I that have seen so many Moons clap their Horns on other mens Foreheads to strike them sick, yet mine to scape, and be well! I that never cast away a Fee upon Urinals, but am as sound as an honest mans Conscience when hee's dying, I should cry out as thou dost, All is not well within me, felt I but the Bag of thy imposthumes. Ah poor Villaine! Ah my wounded Ras∣cal! all my grief is, I have now small hope of thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Do the Surgeons say, My wounds are dangerous then?

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: Ye, yes, and there's no way with thee but one.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Would he were here to open them.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: Ile go to fetch him: Ile make an holiday to see thee as I wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: A wondrous kinde old man.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.P: Your sins the blacker, so to abuse his goodness. Master, how do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Pretty well now, boy: I have such odd qualms come cross my stomack! Ile fall too: boy, cut me.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: You have cut me, I'm sure, a Leg or Wing, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: No, no, no: a Wing? would I had Wings but to soar up you Tower: but here's a Clog that hinders me. What's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: That? what? O now I see her; 'tis a young Wench, my Daughter, Sirrah, sick to the death: and hearing thee to be an ex∣cellent Rascal for letting blood, she looks out at a Casement, and crys, Help, help, stay that man; him I must have, or none.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: For pities sake, remove her: see, she stares with one broad open eye still in my face.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: Thou puttest both hers out, like a Villaine as thou art; yet see, she is willing to lend thee one againe to finde out the Mur∣therer, and that's thy self.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Old man, thou liest.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: So shalt thou i'th' Goal. Run for Officers.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P:
O thou merciless Slave! she was (though yet above ground) in her Grave to me, but thou hast torn it up againe. Mine eyes too
much drown'd, now must feel more raine.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: Fetch Officers.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: For whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: For thee, sirrah, sirrah: some knives have foolish Posies upon them, but thine has a villanous one; look, Oh! it is enam∣meld with the Heart-Blood of thy hated Wife, my beloved Daugh∣ter. What saist thou to this evidence? is't not sharp? does't not strike home? thou canst not answer honestly, and without a trem∣bling heart, to this one point, this terrible bloody point.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.P: I beseech you, Sir, strike him no more; you see he's dead already.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: O, Sir! you held his Horses, you are as arrant a Rogue as he: up, go you too.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: As y'are a man, throw not upon that Woman your loads of tyrannie, for she's innocent.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: How? how? a woman? is't grown to a fashion for wo∣men in all Countries to wear the Breeches?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.P: I am not as my disguise speaks me, Sir, his Page; but his first onely wife, his lawful wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: How? how? more fire i'th' Bed-straw?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.P: The wrongs which singly fell on your Daughter, on me are multiplyed: she lost a life, but I, an Husband and my self must lose, if you call him to a Bar for what he has done.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: He has done it then?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Yes, 'tis confess'd to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Dost thou betray me?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.P: O pardon me, dear heart! I am mad to lose thee, and know not what I speak: but if thou didst, I must arraigne this Father for two sins, Adultery and Murther.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: Sir, they are come.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: Arraigne me for what thou wilt, all Middlesex knows me better for an honest man, then the middle of a Market place knows thee for an honest woman: rise, Sirrah, and don your Tacklings, rig your self for the Gallows, or I'll carry thee thither on my back: your Trull shall to th' Goal go with you; there be as fine New-gate birds as she, that can draw him in. Pox on's wounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I have serv'd thee, and my wages now are paid, Yet my worst punishment shall, I hope, be staid.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: STill wrong'd by every Slave? and not a Dog
Bark in his Dames defence? I am call'd Witch,
Yet am my self bewitched from doing harm.
Have I given up my self to thy black lust
Thus to be scorn'd? not see me in three days?
I'm lost without my Tomalin: prithee come,
Revenge to me is sweeter far then life;
Thou art my Raven, on whose cole - black wings
Revenge comes flying to me: O my best love!
I am on fire, (even in the midst of Ice)
Raking my blood up, till my shrunk knees feel
Thy curl'd head leaning on them. Come then, my Darling,
If in the Aire thou hover'st, fall upon me
In some dark Cloud; and as I oft have seen
Dragons and Serpents in the Elements,
Appear thou now so to me. Art thou i'th' Sea?
Muster up all the Monsters from the deep,
And be the ugliest of them: so that my bulch
Shew but his swarth cheek to me, let earth cleave,
And break from Hell, I care not: could I run
Like a swift Powder-Mine beneath the world,
Up would I blow it, all to finde out thee,
Though I lay ruin'd in it. Not yet come!
I must then fall to my old Prayer:
Not yet come! worrying of Wolves, biting of mad Dogs, the Manges and the—

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: How now! whom art thou cursing?

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: Thee. Ha! No, 'tis my black Cur I am cursing, for not attending▪ on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: I am that Cur.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Thou liest: hence, come not nigh me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Baugh, waugh.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: VVhy dost thou thus appear to me in white, as if thou wert the Ghost of my dear love?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: I am dogged, list not to tell thee, yet to torment thee: my whiteness puts thee in minde of thy winding Sweet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Am I near death?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: Yes, if the Dog of Hell be near thee. VVhen the De∣vil comes to thee as a Lamb, have at thy Throat.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Off, Cur.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: He has the back of a Sheep, but the belly of an Otter: de∣vours by Sea and Land. VVhy am I in white? didst thou not pray to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: Yes, thou dissembling Hell-hound: why now in white more then at other times?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: Be blasted with the News; whiteness is days Foot-boy, a forerunner to light, which shews thy old rivel'd face: Villaines are strip't naked, the Witch must be beaten out of her Cock-pit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Must she? she shall not; thou art a lying Spirit:
Why to mine eyes art thou a Flag of truce?
I am at peace with none; 'tis the black colour
Or none, which I fight under: I do not like
Thy puritan-paleness: glowing Furnaces
Are far more hot then they which flame outright.
If thou my old Dog art, go and bite such as I shall set thee on.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: I will not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: I'll sell my self to twenty thousand Fiends, to have thee orn in pieces then.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: Thou canst not: thou art so ripe to fall into Hell, that no note of my Kennel will so much as bark at him that hangs thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: I shall run mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Do so, thy time is come, to curse, and rave and die.
The Glass of thy sins is full, and it must run out at Gallows.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: It cannot, ugly Cur, I'll confess nothing;
And not confessing, who dare come and swear
have bewitched them? I'll not confess one mouthful.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Chuse, and be hang'd or burn'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: Spight of the Devil and thee, I'll muzzle up my Tongue from telling Tales.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Spight of thee and the Devil, thou'lt be condemn'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Yes, when?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: And ere the Executioner catch thee full in's Claws, thou'lt confess all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Out Dog!

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Out Witch! Thy tryal is at hand:
Our prey being had, the Devil does laughing stand.
SP.STAGE: The Dog stands aloof. Enter Old Banks, Ratchiff, and Countrymen.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.L: She's here; attach her: Witch, you must go with us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Whither? to Hell?

SP.SPEAKER: O. Bank.
SP.P: No, no, no, old Crone; your Mittimus shall be made thither, but your own Jaylors shall receive you. Away with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: My Tommie! my sweet Tom-boy! O thou Dog! dost thou now fly to thy Kennel and forsake me? Plagues and Consum∣ptions—

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Ha, ha, ha, ha!
Let not the World, VVitches or Devils condemn,
They follow us, and then we follow them.

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.P: I would fain meet with mine Ingle once more; he has had a Claw amongst 'um: my Rival that lov'd my VVench, is like to be hang'd like an innocent; a kinde Cur, where he takes; but where he takes not, a dogged Rascal. I know the Villaine loves me: no. [Barks.] Art thou there? that's Toms voice, but 'tis not he: this is a Dog of another hair: this? bark and not speak to me? not Tom then: there's as much difference betwixt Tom and this, as be∣twixt white and black.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Hast thou forgot me?

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.L: That's Tom again: prithee Ningle speak, is thy name Tom?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: VVhilst I serv'd my old Dame Sawyer, 'twas: I'm gone from her now.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: Gone? away with the VVitch then too: shee'll never thrive if thou leav'st her; she knows no more how to kill a Cow, or a Horse, or a Sow, without thee, then she does to kill a Goose.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: No, she has done killing now, but must be kill'd for what she has done: she's shortly to be hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.P: Is she? in my conscience if she be, 'tis thou hast brought her to the Gallows, Tom.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: Right: I serv'd her to that purpose, 'twas part of my VVages.

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.P: This was no honest Servants part, by your leave Tom: this remember, I pray you, between you and I; I entertain'd you ever as a Dog, not as a Devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: True; and so I us'd thee doggedly, not divellishly.
I have deluded thee for sport to laugh at.
The VVench thou seek'st after, thou never spakest with,
But a Spirit in her form, habit and likeness. Ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.P: I do not then wonder at the change of your garments, if you can enter into shapes of VVomen too.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: Any shape, to blind such silly eyes as thine; but chiefly those course Creatures, Dog or Cat, Hare, Ferret, Frog, Toad.

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.L: Louse or Flea?

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Any poor Vermine.

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.P: It seems you Devils have poor thin souls, that you can bestow your selves in such small bodies: but pray you Tom, one question at parting, I think I shall never see you more; where do you borrow those Bodies that are none of your own? the garment∣shape you may hire at Brokers.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: VVhy wouldst thou know that? fool, it availes thee not.

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.P: Onely for my mindes sake, Tom, and to tell some of my Friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: I'll thus much tell thee: Thou never art so distant
From an evil Spirit, but that thy Oaths,
Curses and Blasphemies pull him to thine Elbow:
Thou never telst a lie, but that a Devil
Is within hearing it; thy evil purposes
Are ever haunted; but when they come to act,
As thy Tongue slaundering, bearing false witness.
Thy hand stabbing, stealing, cozening, cheating,
He's then within thee: thou play'st, he bets upon thy part;
Although thou lose, yet he will gaine by thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.L: I? then he comes in the shape of a Rook.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: The old Cadaver of some selfe-strangled wretch
VVe sometimes borrow, and appear humane.
The Carcase of some disease-slain strumpet,
VVe varnish fresh, and wear as her first Beauty.
Didst never hear? if not, it has been done.
An hot luxurious Leacher in his Twines,
When he has thought to clip his Dalliance,
There has provided been for his embrace
A fine hot flaming Devil in her place.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Yes, I am partly a witness to this, but I never could em∣brace her: I thank thee for that, Tom; well, againe I thank thee, Tom, for all this counsel, without a Fee too; there's few Lawyers of thy minde now: certainly Tom, I begin to pity thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Pity me? for what?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Were it not possible for thee to become an honest Dog yet? 'tis a base life that you lead, Tom, to serve VVitches, to kill innocent Children, to kill harmless Cattle, to stroy Corn and Fruit, &c. 'twere better yet to be a Butcher, and kill for your self.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: VVhy? these are all my delights, my pleasures, fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Or Tom, if you could give your minde to ducking, I know you can swim, fetch and carry, some Shop-keeper in London would take great delight in you, and be a tender master over you: or if you have a mind to the Game, either at Bull or Bear, I think I could prefer you to Mal-Cutpurse.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.P: Ha, ha! I should kill all the Game, Bulls, Bears, Dogs, and all, not a Cub to be left.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: You could do, Tom, but you must play fair, you should be stav'd off else: or if your stomach did better like to serve in some Noble Mans, Knights or Gentlemans Kitchin, if you could brook the wheel, and turn the spit, your labour could not be much; when they have Rost-meat, that's but once or twice in the week at most, here you might lick you own Toes very well: Or if you could translate your self into a Ladies Arming-puppy, there you might lick sweet lips, and do many pretty Offices; but to creep un∣der an old VVitches Coats, and suck like a great Puppy, Fie upon't! I have heard beastly things of you, Tom.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Ha, ha! The worse thou heardst of me, the better 'tis.
Shall I serve thee, Fool, at the self-same rate?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: No, I'll see thee hang'd, thou shalt be damn'd first; I know thy qualities too well, Ile give no suck to such VVhelps; therefore henceforth I defie thee; out and avaunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Dog.
SP.L: Nor will I serve for such a silly Soul.
I am for greatness now, corrupted greatness;
There I'll shug in, and get a noble countenance:
Serve some Briarean Footcloth-strider,
That has an hundred hands to catch at Bribes,
But not a Fingers nayl of Charity.
Such, like the Dragons Tayl, shall pull down hundreds
To drop and sink with him: I'll stretch my self,
And draw this Bulk small as a Silver-wire,
Enter at the least pore Tobacco fume
Can make a breach for: hence silly fool,
I scorn to prey on such an Atome soul.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Come out, come out, you Cur; I will beat thee out of the bounds of Edmonton, and to morrow we go in Procession, and af∣ter thou shalt never come in againe: if thou goest to London, I'll make thee go about by Tiburn, stealing in by Theeving Lane: if thou canst rub thy Shoulder against a Lawyers Gown, as thou passest by Westminster-Hall, do; if not, to the Stayers amongst the Bandogs, take water, and the Devil go with thee.
SP.STAGE: Enter Justice, Sir Arthur, Warbeck, Carter, Kate.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Sir Arthur, though the Bench hath mildly censur'd your Errours, yet you have indeed been the Instrument that wrought all their mis-fortunes: I would wish you pay'd down your Fine speedi∣ly and willingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: I'll need no urging to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: If you should, 'twere a shame to you; for if I should speak my conscience, you are worthier to be hang'd of the two, all things considered; and now make what you can of it: but I am glad these Gentlemen are freed.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: We knew our innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: And therefore fear'd it not.

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.L: But I am glad that I have you safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: How now! what noyse is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: Young Frank is going the wrong way: Alas, poor youth! now I begin to pity him.
SP.STAGE: Enter Y. Thorney and Holberts. Enter as to see the Execution, O. Carter, O. Thorney, Katharine, Winnifride weeping.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: Here let our sorrows wait him: to press neerer
The place of his sad death, some apprehensions
May tempt our grief too much, at height already.
Daughter, be comforted.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Comfort and I
Are too far separated to be joyn'd
But in eternity. I share too much of him that's going thither.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: Poor woman, 'twas not thy fault: I grieve to see
Thee weep for him that hath my pity too.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: My fault was lust, my punishment was shame;
Yet I am happy that my soul is free
Both from consent, fore-knowledge and intent
Of any Murther, but of mine own Honour.
Restor'd again by a fair satisfaction, and since not to be wounded.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.P: Daughter, grieve not for what necessity forceth; rather resolve to conquer it with patience. Alas, she faints!

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.P: My griefes are strong upon me: my weakness scarce can bear hem.

SP.SPEAKER: Within.
SP.L: Away with her! hang her, Witch!
SP.STAGE: Enter Sawyes to Execution, Officers with Holberts, country-people.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: The Witch, that instrument of mischief! did not she witch the Devil into my Son-in-law, when he kill'd my poor Daughter? do you hear, Mother Sawyer?

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: What would you have? cannot a poor old woman have your leave to die without vexation?

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: Did not you bewitch Frank to kill his wife? he could ne∣ver have don't without the Devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Who doubts it? but is every Devil mine?
VVould I had one now whom I might command
To tear you all in pieces: Tom would have don't before he left me.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: Thou did'st bewitch Anne Ratcliff to kill her self.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.P: Churl, thou ly'st; I never did her hurt: would you were all as neer your ends as I am, that gave evidence against me for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Countr.
SP.P: I'll be sworn, Mr. Carter, she bewitched Gammer Wa∣bowls Sow, to cast her Pigs a day before she would have farried; et they were sent up to London, and sold for as good Westminster Dog-Pigs, at Bartholomew Fair, as ever great belly'd Ale-wife longed for.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: These Dogs will mad me: I was well resolv'd
To die in my repentance; though 'tis true.
I would live longer if I might: yet since
I cannot, pray torment me not; my conscience
Is setled as it shall be, all take heed
How they believe the Devil, at last hee'l cheat you.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: Th'adst best confess all truly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sawy.
SP.L: Yet again?
Have I scarce breath enough to say my Prayers?
And would you force me to spend that in bawling?
Bear witness, I repent all former evil▪
There is no damned Conjurer like the Devil.

SP.SPEAKER: Omn.
SP.L: Away with her, away!
SP.STAGE: Fnter Frank to Execution, Officers, Iustice, Sir Arthur. Warbeck, Somerton.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: Here's the sad Object which I yet must meet
VVith hope of comfort, if a repentant end
Make him more happy then mis-fortune would
Suffer him here to be.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Good Sire, turn from me;
You will revive affliction almost kil'd
With my continual sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: O Thor.
SP.L: VVould I had sunk in mine own wants, or died
But one bare minute ere thy fault was acted.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: To look upon your sorrows, executes me before my Exe∣cution.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Let me pray you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Thou much wrong'd woman, I must sigh for thee,
As he that's onely loath to leave the World,
For that he leaves thee in it unprovided,
Unfriended; and for me to beg a pity
From any man to thee when I am gone,
Is more then I can hope; nor to say truth,
Have I deserv'd it: but there is a payment
Belongs to goodness from the great Exchequer
Above, it will not fail thee, Winnifride;
Be that thy comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: Let it be thine too,
Untimely lost young man.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: He is not lost,
VVho bears his peace within him: had I spun
My VVeb of life out at full length, and dream'd
Away my many years in lusts, in surfeits,
Murthers of Reputations, gallant fins
Commended or approv'd; then though I had
Died easily, as great and rich men do,
Upon my own Bed, not compell'd by Justice,
You might have mourn'd for me indeed; my miseries
Had been as everlasting, as remediless:
But now the Law hath not arraign'd, condemn'd
VVith greater rigour my unhappy Fact,
Then I my self have every little sin
My memory can reckon from my Child-hood:
A Court hath been kept here, where I am found
Guilty; the difference is, my impartial Judge
Is much more gracious then my Faults
Are monstrous to be nam'd; yet they are monstrous.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: Here's comfort in this penitence.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: It speaks
How truly you are reconcil'd, and quickens
My dying comfort, that was neer expiring
With my last breath: now this Repentance makes thee
As white as innocence; and my first sin with thee,
Since which I knew none like it, by my sorrow,
Is clearly cancell'd: might our Souls together
Climb to the height of their eternity,
And there enjoy what earth denied us, Happiness:
But since I must survive, and be the monument
Of thy lov'd memory, I will preserve it
VVith a Religious care, and pay thy ashes
A VVidows duty, calling that end best,
VVhich though it stain the name, makes the soul blest

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Give me thy hand, poor woman: do not weep:
Farewel. Thou dost forgive me?

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: 'Tis my part
To use that Language

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Oh that my Example
Might teach the VVorld hereafter what a curse
Hangs on their heads, who rather chuse to marry
A goodly Portion, then a Dowr of Vertues!
Are you there, Gentlemen? there is not one
Amongst you whom I have not wrong'd: you most;
rob'd you of a Daughter; but she is
In Heaven; and I must suffer for it willingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: I, I, she's in Heaven, and I am glad to see
Thee so well prepared to follow her:
I forgive thee with all my heart; if thou
Had'st not had ill counsel, thou would'st not have
Done as thou didst: the more shame for them.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: Spare your excuse to me, I do conceive
What you would speak: I would you could as easily
Make satisfaction to the Law, as to my wrongs.
I am sorry for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Warb.
SP.L: And so am I, and heartily forgive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: I will pray for you, for her sake, who, I am sure, did love you dearly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.P: Let us part friendly too: I am asham'd of my part in thy wrongs.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: You are all merciful, and send me to my Grave in peace. Sir Arthur, Heavens send you a new heart. Lastly to you, Sir; and though I have deserv'd not to be call'd your Son, yet give me leave upon my knees, to beg a blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.L: Take it: let me wet thy Cheeks with the last
Tears my griefs have left me. O Frank, Frank, Frank!

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Let me beseech you, Gentlemen, to
Comfort my old Father; keep him with yee;
Love this distressed VVidow; and as often
As you remember what a graceless man
I was, remember likewise that these are
Both free, both worthy of a better Fate,
Then such a Son or Husband as I have been.
All help me with your prayers. On, on, 'tis just
That Law should purge the guilt of blood and lust.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: Go thy ways: I did not think to have shed one tear for thee, but thou hast made me water my plants spight of my heart. M. Thorney, chear up, man; whilst I can stand by you, you shall not want help to keep you from falling. We have lost our Children both on's the wrong way, but we cannot help it: better or worse, 'tis now as 'tis.

SP.SPEAKER: O. Thor.
SP.P: I thank you, Sir, you are more kinde then I have cause to hope or look for.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: Mr. Somerton, is Kate yours or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: We are agreed,

SP.SPEAKER: Kat.
SP.P: And, but my Faith is pass'd, I should fear to bemarried Husbands are so cruelly unkind: excuse me that I am thus troubled.

SP.SPEAKER: Som.
SP.L: Thou shalt have no cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.L: Take comfort Mistris Winnifride. Sir Arthur,
For his abuse to you, and to your Husband,
Is by the Bench enjoyn'd to pay you down
A thousand Marks.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Art.
SP.L: Which I will soon discharge.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: Sir, 'tis too great a sum to be imploy'd upon my Funeral.

SP.SPEAKER: Cart.
SP.P: Come, come, if luck had serv'd, Sir Arthur, and every ma had his due, somebody might have totter'd ere this, without pay¦ing Fines: like it as you list. Come to me Winnifride, shalt be wel come: make much of her, Kate, I charge you: I do not think bu she's a good Wench, and hath has wrong as well as we. So let' every man home to Edmonton with heavy hearts, yet as merry a we can, though not as we would.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.L: Joyn Friends in sorrow; make of all the best:
Harms past may be lamented, not redrest.

SP.SPEAKER: Win.
SP.L: I Am a Widow still, and must not sort
A second choice, without a good report;
Which though some Widows finde, and few deserve,
Yet I dare not presume, but will not swerve
From modest hopes. All noble tongues are free;
The gentle may speak one kinde word for me.
